May 22: Weyerhaeuser Acquiring High-Quality Timberlands in North Carolina and Virginia

Capitalizing on unique off-market opportunity to further enhance Southern Timberlands portfolio with highly productive and strategically located acreage

SEATTLE, May 22, 2025 - Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) today announced an agreement to acquire approximately 117,000 acres of high-quality timberlands in North Carolina and Virginia from Roanoke Timberlands LLC, a subsidiary of Roseburg Forest Products, for $375 million. Comprised of mature, highly productive timberlands, the acreage will be well-integrated with existing Weyerhaeuser timberland and mill operations in North Carolina, will expand the company's footprint into attractive markets in southeastern Virginia and will offer substantial alternative value opportunities. The acquisition is expected to deliver immediate and sustained portfolio-leading cash flows within the company's Southern Timberlands business.

Key attributes of the acquisition:

Located in strong and growing sawlog and fiber markets in the U.S. South Primarily fee ownership with 81 percent planted pine acreage, strong site productivity and favorable all-weather logging operability Mature planted pine age class expected to produce an average annual harvest of 7.4 tons per acre (or 860,000 tons) over the first five years Expected to deliver an average annual timber free cash flow yield of 5.1 percent over the first five years Significant optionality to capture additional upside from real estate, natural climate solutions and natural resource opportunities "These are exceptional timberlands, and we're excited and well-positioned to capitalize on this unique off-market opportunity," said Devin W. Stockfish, president and chief executive officer. "As we've demonstrated over the last several years, we are committed to active portfolio management across our unmatched timber holdings and have remained disciplined in our approach to growing the value of our timberlands - including through strategically targeted private transactions like the one we're announcing today.

May 21: Weyerhaeuser to Sell Princeton, B.C., Lumber Mill to Gorman Group

Agreement with local buyer includes manufacturing facility and associated timber licenses in British Columbia

SEATTLE, May 21, 2025 - Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) today announced it has reached an agreement to sell its lumber mill in Princeton, British Columbia, to the Gorman Group, owners of Gorman Bros.Lumber Ltd., a family-owned wood products manufacturer headquartered in West Kelowna, B.C. The purchase price is approximately $120 million CAD in cash, which includes Weyerhaeuser's manufacturing facility, all associated timber license assets in British Columbia and the value of working capital, which will be subject to customary purchase price adjustments at closing.

Weyerhaeuser and Gorman Group have a long-standing relationship in Canada. Gorman Bros.Lumber is currently the Princeton mill's largest customer, and Gorman Group has operated in Canada for more than 75 years, with offices and facilities in B.C. and Washington state.

"We are grateful to all the dedicated employees who contributed to the success of our Princeton operations over the years," says Devin W. Stockfish, president and chief executive officer for Weyerhaeuser. "The community has always been incredibly welcoming and supportive of our mill and people, and it was important for us to sell to a local buyer with deep roots in the region. Gorman has been a great customer and strategic partner, and we believe this will be a seamless transition that will position the mill for future success in a challenging operating environment - providing long-term certainty for the mill and the broader community."

"Weyerhaeuser's Princeton operation will be a natural fit with the Gorman Group," says Nick Arkle, chief executive officer of the Gorman Group. "We've had a strong connection to the Princeton operation for many years, and we know firsthand the skill, commitment and quality that define its team.

WHAT YOU WILL FIND IN THIS MD&A

ECONOMIC AND MARKET CONDITIONS AFFECTING OUR OPERATIONS

Our market conditions and the strength of the broader U.S. economy are, and will continue to be, influenced by the trajectory of activity in the U.S. housing and repair and remodel segments, inflation trends and interest rates. The demand for sawlogs within our Timberlands segment is directly affected by domestic production of wood-based building products. The strength of the U.S. housing market, particularly new residential construction, strongly affects demand in our Wood Products segment, as does repair and remodeling activity. Seasonal weather patterns impact the level of construction activity in the U.S., which in turn affects demand for our logs and wood products. Our Timberlands segment, specifically the Western region, is also affected by export demand and trade policy. Japanese housing starts are a key driver of export log demand in Japan. The demand for pulpwood from our Timberlands segment is directly affected by the production of pulp, paper and oriented strand board (OSB), as well as the demand for biofuels, such as wood-burning pellets made from pulpwood. Our Timberlands segment is also influenced by the availability of harvestable timber. SECTION 5 WEYERHAEUSER 10-Q: 12 CONSEQUENTIAL MANAGEMENT DECISIONS

Strategic Expansion of Engineered Wood Products Capacity

Management has committed $500 million to constructing a new TimberStrand facility in Monticello, Arkansas, beginning in 2025, with operations expected by 2027. This investment is projected to expand engineered wood products capacity by 10 million cubic feet, positioning Weyerhaeuser to seize greater market share in the growing housing sector. While the long-term growth and revenue potential align with favorable housing trends, the funding approach-whether via existing cash or external financing-could pressure short-term liquidity or increase debt levels.

Shareholder Value Enhancement Through New $1 Billion Buyback Program

Following completion of a prior program, management authorized a new $1 billion share repurchase initiative in May 2025. This move underscores confidence in company valuation and enhances earnings per share by reducing outstanding shares. While the initiative aligns with the shareholder return framework targeting 75-80% of Adjusted FAD, it reflects a strategic trade-off by potentially limiting capital allocation flexibility during potential market volatility.

Maintaining Dividend Stability Amid Economic Challenges

Weyerhaeuser continues its cash dividend framework, targeting a 75-80% payout of Adjusted FAD, and has paid $304 million in 2025 dividends thus far. The year-to-date payout decline-due primarily to an absence of supplemental dividends in Q1-highlights the company's adaptability to fluctuating cash flows. For income-focused investors, this consistent dividend policy provides predictability, though variability in Adjusted FAD may influence future distributions.

Strengthened Liquidity with an Updated Credit Facility

The company amended and restated its revolving credit facility in June 2025, increasing capacity to $1.75 billion and extending maturity to 2030. This ensures access to substantial liquidity without current borrowings, providing operational flexibility while reducing refinancing risks during economic uncertainty. The alignment of covenant compliance further supports Weyerhaeuser's credit profile.

Capital Optimization through Debt Repayment and Refinancing

Management refinanced maturing debt by repaying $210 million in debentures while issuing a $300 million senior unsecured term loan maturing in 2030. This strategic action reduced the weighted average interest rate, trimming interest expense by $2 million year-to-date, while preserving $592 million in cash and full credit availability. For investors, this showcases disciplined capital allocation, though possible fluctuations in interest rates remain a key consideration.

Focused Capital Investments to Drive Operational Efficiency

Excluding the Monticello project, management outlined $400 million in planned 2025 capital expenditures, with $200 million deployed so far. This includes both Timberland and Wood Products maintenance expansions designed to sustain production efficiency. Despite a year-over-year increase, such investments affirm a long-term strategy to sharpen competitiveness-though revenue pressure could strain cash flow in adverse market conditions.

Expansion into Carbon Markets to Capture Sustainability Growth

Weyerhaeuser progresses in leveraging its natural climate solutions, capitalizing on the growing demand for carbon credits and renewable energy. By positioning itself within key sustainability sectors, management aims to unlock new revenue streams while aligning with global decarbonization goals. Though regulatory adjustments and market development require monitoring, this initiative offers potential upside for forward-looking investors.

Unlocking Value Through Strategic Divestitures

The announced sale of a wood products manufacturing facility (pending regulatory approvals) reflects Weyerhaeuser's strategy to streamline operations and optimize its asset base. If successful, this move could free up cash for reinvestment in higher-margin opportunities and improve overall profitability. However, pending closures introduce timing uncertainties for short-term financial performance.

Timberland Acquisition to Strengthen Strategic Resource Base

Management advanced a timberland acquisition that remains subject to regulatory approval. This investment supports long-term timber supply needs for the Timberlands segment while positioning the company in tightening log markets. The targeted synergies enhance revenue potential, though integration risks and upfront costs require careful oversight.

Operational Efficiency Improvements Amid Inflationary Pressures

Initiatives to restructure manufacturing processes and reduce costs address inflation-driven challenges related to raw materials, energy, and labor. By improving cost structures, Weyerhaeuser aims to mitigate margin compression and enhance profitability. Successful implementation will be key, especially given labor market constraints influencing production continuity.

Proactive Risk Management for Contingent Liabilities

Reserves for litigation and environmental responsibilities demonstrate management's financial diligence in safeguarding against operational uncertainties. By maintaining adequate coverage for contingent liabilities, Weyerhaeuser bolsters its balance sheet resilience. However, potential over-reserving may tie up capital unnecessarily and requires vigilant management assessment.

Prioritizing Workforce Stability Amid Labor Market Tightness

Recognizing a 4.1% unemployment rate as a constraint, Weyerhaeuser focused on hiring and talent retention across its segments. Stability in workforce availability ensures operational continuity and supports management's strategic initiatives. However, rising labor costs remain a potential margin-pressure risk-a critical area to monitor for sustained profitability.

urn:contentItem:6GKD-DFT3-RRR5-S2XG-00000-00Arganil fire already the biggest ever in Portugal in terms of area burned2025-08-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:50:23ZLexisNexisArganil fire already the biggest ever in Portugal in terms of area burned


The fire that broke out in Arganil on August 13 is the largest area ever burned in Portugal, with 64,000 hectares consumed, according to the provisional report from the Institute for Nature Conservation and Forests (ICNF).
The fire that started in Piódão, in the municipality of Arganil (district of Coimbra), and which was put out on Sunday after 11 days, has burned 64,451 hectares, according to the provisional national report from the ICNF's Forest Fire Information Management System (SGIF), to which the Lusa news agency had access.


The report, with the latest update of the burnt area made on Sunday, confirms that this fire is the largest area ever burnt in Portugal since records began, surpassing the previous mark of the fire that started in Vilarinho, in the municipality of Lousã, in October 2017, which had reached 53,000 hectares.
The fire that started in Arganil also affected the municipalities of Pampilhosa da Serra and Oliveira do Hospital (Coimbra district), Seia (Guarda) and Castelo Branco, Fundão and Covilhã (Castelo Branco).
This year, according to the SGIF report, around 250,000 hectares have already burned.
The fire that started in Freches, Trancoso, on the 9th, is thought to have consumed 49,324 hectares and is the second largest this year and the third largest fire ever in Portugal.
The fire with the third largest area burnt this year, according to the SGIF report consulted by Lusa, was in Sátão, with 13,769 hectares, which joined Trancoso to form a complex that affected 11 municipalities in the districts of Viseu and Guarda.
Freixo de Espada à Cinta (11,697 hectares), the two fires in Sabugal (10,539 and 10,403), another fire in Trancoso that started on the 14th (8,673), Guarda (7,151) and Vila Real (6,007) are also on the list of the 10 biggest fires this year, all of which occurred in August.
In the list of the 10 biggest fires, there was only one fire in July, in Ponte da Barca (7,164), according to the report consulted by Lusa.
Up until Sunday, there had been 80 major fires (with an area of more than 100 hectares) in Portugal this year, accounting for 97% of the country's total burnt area, the SGIF concluded.
According to the SGIF's provisional report, Guarda, Viseu and Castelo Branco are the districts with the most burned area.
Covilhã (20,257), Sabugal (18,726) and Trancoso (17,239 hectares) are the municipalities most affected by the fires in terms of area burnt, followed by Sernancelhe, Mêda, Arganil and Penedono, all municipalities with more than 10,000 hectares burnt.
On Wednesday, Paulo Fernandes, a researcher at the University of Trás-os-Montes and Alto Douro (UTAD), predicted that the Arganil fire could be the biggest ever in Portugal, considering that it had the conditions to become huge.
The fire started at dawn, from two lightning strikes, on a ridge that was difficult to access, and spread very quickly in the first few hours, the fire expert and member of the technical committees analyzing the major fires of 2017 told Lusa.
The fire progressed in a territory that was difficult to access and in a region that burned successively, with "a continuum of increasingly homogeneous vegetation" that contributed to the fire's progression, he explained.

urn:contentItem:6GKC-1YW3-RSTJ-230B-00000-00Europe's summer wildfires break terrifying record as 1 MILLION hectares scorched2025-08-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:50:23ZLexisNexisWORLD NEWSVersion:1Europe's summer wildfires break terrifying record as 1 MILLION hectares scorchedBy, Nada Farhoud

The European Union has seen more than one million hectares scorched by wildfires for the first time in 2025 since records began in 1996, according to official data

Wildfires have torched more than one million hectares across countries in the European Union this year, making 2025 the worst on record.

The data shows records have also been broken for the amount of Co2 and other air pollutants entering the atmosphere, a full month before the fire season ends. So far this summer deadly infernos have emptied out villages and forced farmers to become firefighters, engulfing four times as much land this year as the average for the same period over the past two decades, according to official data.

The European Forest Fire Information System Effis, which goes back to 2003, shows 1,015,024 hectares have burned this year - breaking the previous record of 988,544 hectares that was set in 2017, with weeks of dangerous fire weather still to come.

The destructive blazes have also pumped out 37m tonnes of carbon dioxide - about as much as the yearly CO2 emissions of Portugal or Sweden, each home to 10 million people. The fires have also broken records for this time of year for nine other air pollutants, including fine particulates known as PM2.5 that experts say make wildfires far more deadly than previously thought.

Cristina Santín Nuño, a fire scientist at the Spanish National Research Council, said the "perfect conditions" for big and dangerous wildfires were happening more and more because of changes in the climate and how people used the land. "It is sad and scary - my home region is burning right now - but not surprising, really," she said.

Wildfires ripped through swathes of southern Europe this month as a heatwave pushed temperatures above 40C across much of the Mediterranean and the Balkans. The flames are known to have killed more than a dozen people but scientists say the hidden death toll is likely to be far greater.

A study published in the Lancet in December blamed wildfire smoke for 111,000 deaths a year in Europe, including Russia, between 2000 and 2019. On Tuesday, the EU's Copernicus atmosphere monitoring service found that "unprecedented" fire activity this year had driven Spain's wildfire emissions up to the highest annual total in the 23 years since records began.

Fumes from fires across the Iberian peninsula were made worse by smoke drifting across the Atlantic from Canada, which has also burned badly in recent weeks. Wildfire emissions from Spain and Portugal in August have been "exceptional", said Mark Parrington, a scientist with Copernicus.

"The large quantities of smoke - and especially PM2.5 - released into the atmosphere have resulted in severely degraded air quality locally, and further afield across the Iberian peninsula and parts of France."

Effis said on Tuesday that fire weather conditions were expected to ease across most of southern Europe this week, but added that "very high to very extreme" anomalies were expected in north-west Europe.

Santín Nuño said a "catastrophic" wildfire season was unlikely every year, but that each year the probability of breaking records was increasing.

It is "highly probable" the record in 2025 will be broken again in a few years, she added. "This is a new reality. And the sooner we realise it, and take action to be more resilient to these types of wildfires, the better."

urn:contentItem:6GK6-7CH3-RT3T-T096-00000-00Spain's recent heatwave most intense on record: agency2025-08-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:50:23ZLexisNexisSpain's recent heatwave most intense on record: agencyNew Delhi


Madrid, Aug 25 (IANS) Spain's State Meteorological Agency (AEMET) has said that the heatwave striking the country this August was the most intense on record, both in terms of temperatures and impacts.



According to provisional data, average temperatures during the August 3-18 period were 4.6 degrees Celsius above the seasonal norm, surpassing the previous record of 4.5 degrees Celsius set in July 2022, Xinhua News Agency reported.

AEMET noted that August 8-17 marked the hottest 10 consecutive days since at least 1950, while the first 20 days of August were the hottest for that period since at least 1961. The days of August 11, 16, and 17 rank among the 10 hottest days registered in Spain since 1941.

Since records began in 1975, Spain has experienced 77 heatwaves. Six of these saw temperatures exceed the average by 4 degrees Celsius, with five occurring since 2019, indicating a trend toward longer and more intense heatwaves.

According to the government's Daily Mortality Monitoring System, this year's heatwaves have caused 1,149 deaths.

In addition, the extreme heat coincided with Spain's worst month of wildfires on record. Data from the European Forest Fire Information System show that 406,100 hectares of land, roughly 5.5 times the size of Singapore, have been burned.

The fires have claimed four lives and forced over 30,000 people to evacuate. Most evacuees have since returned, but many wildfires remained active as of Sunday.

Earlier, on August 22, the World Health Organisation (WHO) and the World Meteorological Organisation (WMO) urged global action to address the escalating health threats posed by extreme heat to workers worldwide.

The year 2024 marked the hottest one on record, with daytime temperatures exceeding 40 degrees centigrade, even 50 degrees centigrade in some regions, a phenomenon which is becoming increasingly common, according to a comprehensive report and technical guidance jointly released by the WHO and WMO.

"Heat stress is already harming the health and livelihoods of billions of workers, especially in the most vulnerable communities," said Jeremy Farrar, assistant director-general for health promotion, disease prevention and care at the WHO.

Health risks, including heatstroke, dehydration, kidney dysfunction and neurological disorders, are undermining the long-term health and economic stability of workers worldwide, said the report, adding that approximately half of the global population has already experienced adverse effects from high temperatures.

Occupational heat stress has become a global challenge, not just confined to countries close to the Equator, as highlighted by the recent heatwave in Europe, said WMO Deputy Secretary-General Ko Barrett. "Protection of workers from extreme heat is not just a health imperative but an economic necessity," Barrett said.

The guidance outlines a multi-stakeholder approach to mitigate risks, including developing national policies, prioritising vulnerable groups, as well as fostering collaboration among governments, employers, trade unions and health experts.

Meanwhile, a Barcelona-based climatologist said that the devastating wildfires sweeping across Spain this summer should serve as a warning to the rest of Europe about the rising dangers of climate change.

"This is a warning to countries that have traditionally enjoyed temperate, cool summers... because these conditions of intense heat will increase in latitude and will reach these countries," Javier Martin-Vide, climatologist and professor of physical geography at the University of Barcelona, told Xinhua.

--IANS

urn:contentItem:6GPX-96N3-RTDF-G2W9-00000-00New bombshell report in Kawhi Leonard scandal should move NBA to impose major penalties2025-09-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:50:23ZLexisNexisSPORTS/NBAPg. 1New bombshell report in Kawhi Leonard scandal should move NBA to impose major penaltiesBruce Arthur

Steve Ballmer is so rich that estimating his net worth is tricky. It was estimated at $153 billion (U.S.) in May, and at least $171 billion now, so by the time you read this who knows how much money he'll have. The owner of the Los Angeles Clippers could probably buy the entire NBA, if the rules allowed.

But then, Ballmer doesn't seem like a stickler for rules, and as the Kawhi Leonard salary cap circumvention case continues to unfold, the Clippers owner should see if he can purchase some plausible explanations. On Thursday, investigative podcaster Pablo Torre surfaced another piece of the puzzle: When Clippers sponsor and failing climate finance bank Aspiration was late with a secret, no-show job $1.75-million installment payment to Clippers star Kawhi Leonard in December of 2022, a $1.990 million investment rolled in that neatly covered the cost, just nine days before Leonard was paid.

Who was responsible for that investment, as Aspiration was laying off employees and burning through money like a forest fire? That would be Dennis Wong, the Clippers vice-chairman, a minority owner - he is the only person other than Ballmer to own a slice of the Clippers - and, as it happens, Ballmer's college roommate at Harvard. Ballmer, of course, had invested $50 million of his own money into Aspiration in 2021.

Shortly after that $50-million infusion, Leonard signed a four-year, $28-million deal with Aspiration that was never announced, with a contract that specified Leonard did not need to do anything for the money. Boston Sports Journal reported Leonard received another $20 million in stock in the company. This, too, was never announced.

And now one of Ballmer's closest friends and partners has been found sending money just in time to cover a payment that was deemed critical within a collapsing company, to a basketball player who didn't do anything for the company.

Basically, this story is a test of both people's intelligence, and of the NBA itself. As the Star reported this week, Leonard's uncle Dennis Robertson asked the Toronto Raptors for the same set of perks in 2019 that Leonard was receiving from the Clippers in 2021: lucrative no-show sponsorships, and ownership stakes in outside companies. (Robertson, who had not done his research, presumed the Toronto Maple Leafs were an outside company, and asked for a piece.)

So Leonard asked that of the Raptors, looks like he got it from the Clippers, and because the vehicle was a company that was more or less a cardboard box painted green and left in the rain, the whole thing went belly-up and just enough of the arrangement was exposed. This is smoke, and fire.

And all that said, NBA commissioner Adam Silver spoke on the subject Wednesday following a board of governors meeting in New York, and he left the door open to closing the door on this. Yes, he said the commissioner's powers are "very broad. Full range of financial penalties, draft picks, suspensions, etcetera. Very broad powers in these situations." And Silver said, correctly, "I have an obligation to be the steward of the brand and the integrity of the league."

But Silver also did something very specific: he emphasized that the burden of proof is on the league, and said "I would be reluctant to act if there was sort of a mere appearance of impropriety. I think the goal of a full investigation is to find out if there really was impropriety, because also in a public facing sport, again, the public, at times, reaches conclusions that later to turn out to be completely false."

It felt like a signal that absent actual proof, the Clippers could theoretically escape serious punishment. The 2019 investigation into Leonard and the Clippers couldn't find proof of wrongdoing, so it's easy to imagine this was all executed with a handshake deal between an owner and a player, and financial transactions which took place outside of team communications channels with no written statement of intent.

With a little work Silver should arrive at major penalties here: a Ballmer suspension, the forfeiture of draft picks, any fine he can finagle, perhaps the voiding of Leonard's current contract, and maybe moving the All-Star Game. Staples Center, after all, is just across town, and nobody would have to change their hotel room.

But while this may obviously be the worst case of cap circumvention in league history, it's at least possible that may not be enough. Silver at least seems reluctant to use the full power of his office and the leeway of the CBA based on an IQ test. And you could understand, really. Ballmer is a titan in the league, the richest owner there is, so while he may be short of explanations, he's not short of that. It's only the integrity of the league, after all.

urn:contentItem:6GKF-M0M3-RRRY-W2GK-00000-00Ignore the igneous, by La Vanguardia2025-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:50:23ZLexisNexisIgnore the igneous, by La Vanguardia


Compared to the summers of 2023 and 2024, the summer of 2025 is being extremely virulent with a tragic balance of human lives, threat to populations and properties, and destructive impact on an important extension of the natural environment. It is urgent to review fire legislation and realistically plan prevention, land use, forest management, early warning and extinction, with experts in each area.


In the face of this national emergency, we must stop political confrontation and apply solutions. Scientific knowledge is the key to reducing "sixth generation" fires, which pessimists consider uncontrollable, especially when, short-sightedly, they think only of increasing modestly paid human resources. The climatic emergency, rural abandonment and lack of planning have multiplied the risk.
"Strategies against fires require decisive political action".
Fire initiation and spread depend on fuel, ignition, atmosphere and topography. Reducing fuel requires planned land management and sustainable use of agroforestry resources. Developments in the forest interface require low fuel load areas and self-protection measures. The law against arsonists must be strengthened, along with surveillance, cleaning of facilities and warning systems.
Minimizing the most flammable biomass would reduce fire intensity and phenomena such as pyrocumulus. The definition of priority zones, adapted firebreaks and numerical simulations supported by artificial intelligence can guide extinguishing strategies.
"Sooner rather than later, we may suffer major forest fires in Spain" was the prescient statement in the conclusions of the seminar Forest Fires in Spain which, in October 2024 and organized by the Royal Academy of Engineering and the Center for Forest Science and Technology of Catalonia, brought together in Madrid experts in fire prevention, management of the rural environment and mathematical simulation of their spread. The consensus was general: neither firefighting teams nor forest fire experts can plan strategies to deal with this threat without decisive political action.
The equation is simple: climate change has led us to new scenarios that we are able to foresee, but extreme fires are a reality that generates its own conditions to advance unchecked. Today, not only their control but also the prediction and simulation of these fires is a challenge that is still unapproachable.
Global and integrative thinking is needed. Prevention involves revaluing forest resources, recovering the agricultural mosaic and containing the expansion of the forest. In Catalonia, it already occupies 15% more than 30 years ago. With scientific criteria, it is necessary to redraw the territory and balance rural, agricultural and forestry uses. Spain has the scientific knowledge to promote profound changes that turn nature into an ally in the face of climate change and activate a bioeconomy of the future.
We propose an applied research program on forest fires to lead this challenge and prepare the territory for potential major fires. A program that could be linked to the 2023 declaration of the Pau Costa Foundation to allocate at least 1 billion euros per year to this mission.
The challenge is enormous and the increasing frequency of fires in Korea, California, the Iberian Peninsula and southeastern Europe proves it. Climate change will not stop, but its effects can be mitigated with science and political consensus.

urn:contentItem:6GNB-4G83-RTX7-G2FN-00000-00Machu Picchu to stop receiving five million visitors between 2020 and 2024, according to IPE2025-09-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:50:23ZLexisNexisMachu Picchu to stop receiving five million visitors between 2020 and 2024, according to IPE

Machu Picchu stopped receiving five million visitors between 2020 and 2024, according to the IPE.To reverse this trend and recover the dynamism of tourism in Cusco and the Inca citadel, leadership and political decision are required, say experts.

Forest fire near Machu Picchu keeps alert active in Cusco

Marcela Marañón, the Peruvian who conquered the 7 wonders of the world in wheelchair

Daniel Tapia
Machu Picchu faces a series of structural problems and worrying inaction on the part of the State. According to estimates by the Peruvian Institute of Economics (IPE), between 2020 and 2024, the Inca citadel of Cusco would have stopped receiving five million visitors compared to the trend it registered before the pandemic.


Listen to the newsText converted into audio
See summary
and highlights of the article with Artificial IntelligenceJoin our politics and economics channel
This drop is not only due to the previous impact of the coronavirus and social conflicts, but also responds to the lack of sustained investment in infrastructure, connectivity and tourism promotion, which has impacted job creation in the region. For example, in the last six years, one third of direct and indirect employment generated by this economic activity has been lost.
"We lack connectivity, infrastructure, airports and developing other tourist circuits. For years we have assumed that Machu Picchu alone would boost national tourism, but without investment and efficient management, that potential is being lost. On the way, if we do not pay attention to these problems, we are going to run out of rope and goat," said Carlos Gallardo, general manager of IPE.
In 2024, Machu Picchu received 1.5 million visitors, which still represents 77,000 fewer visits than in 2019, and approximately 500,000 fewer than it would have achieved if it recovered the trend of the five years prior to the pandemic.
Machu Picchu in trouble: it received fewer tourists
Between January and July of this year, the Cusco archaeological complex was the scene of the arrival of 675,000 foreign tourists, a figure that is 3.6% lower than the similar period of 2019, when it reached an amount of 700,000 visitors. According to Roger Valencia, president of the Cusco Institute of Economics (INCUSE), Machu Picchu is going through a stage of aging as a tourist destination.
"One of the symptoms of this aging is a chronic strangulation of mobility. Another characteristic of this phenomenon is that there is a great diversity of types of lodging with little planning and an evident crisis in public transportation. Something that is beginning to be noticed is the decrease in tourist spending and the rate of permanence of the traveler," explained the specialist.
In view of this situation, Valencia proposed renewing the image of the destination, incorporating new attractions and modernizing the management of the space with a focus on improving the visitor's experience. To achieve this, he considered it essential to expand not only the sanctuary's visitor area, but also to integrate the circuit with tourist attractions in other provinces, such as Anta and La Convención.
For his part, Juan Stoessel, CEO of Casa Andina, noted that Machu Picchu generates around S/220 million annually in ticket sales alone, but has not received significant investment for several years. He recalled thatUNESCO has supported the creation of visitor centers and the enhancement of the Inca trails, which shows that there is technical feasibility.
Likewise, he raised his voice of surprise for the absence of a mechanized, orderly and safe access to the Inca citadel, as well as the lack of a connection to the Amazon area. In his opinion, the only thing that is needed to address these problems is political decision, since there is no economic problem involved.
"Every dollar invested is multiplied in employment for the communities and economic dynamism for the entire tourist circuit in the south. We have to stop thinking about benefiting a few and that we can't do better. We must think big: how to make this place last for centuries to come. Sustainability is important," he said.

urn:contentItem:6GJS-G0W3-RS1P-J0N4-00000-00Spain begins to put out the most serious fires, although nineteen are still active2025-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:50:23ZLexisNexisSpain begins to put out the most serious fires, although nineteen are still active


Spain continues the 'de-escalation' of the wave of forest fires, the worst of the century, after extinguishing several serious outbreaks and stabilizing the increase of hectares razed thanks to improved weather conditions, although there are still nineteen active fires in the north and west of the territory.


The President of Spain, Pedro Sánchez, announced this Friday the activation of the "path" towards a State pact against fires after advancing the launching next Tuesday of an inter-ministerial commission on climate change to address this emergency.
During his visit to the region of Asturias (north), one of those affected by the fire, Sanchez said he will take this issue to the next meeting of the Conference of Presidents, the highest political level of cooperation between the Spanish State and the regions, before the end of the year to "define and implement all policies that have to do with prevention, with the response and with the subsequent reconstruction".
The Ministry of the Interior informed this Friday during the meeting of the State Committee of Coordination and Direction (Cecod) that nineteen fires remain active this Friday in Operational Situation 2, in the autonomous communities of Castilla y León (center-north), Galicia (north-west) and Extremadura (west).
According to data released by Cecod, eleven of these outbreaks are in Castilla y León, six in Galicia and one in Extremadura.
In fact, the latest update of the edu.forestry.es tool, based on the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS), shows that the fire raged in the north of the country, particularly in Galicia and Castilla y León, which accounted for 79% of the burned hectares.
The estimate was made by edu.forestry.es experts on the 51 Large Forest Fires, those fires that reach 500 hectares of surface razed by the flames, which places these two autonomous communities as the most affected.
The weather conditions favored the work of the extinguishing teams during the night of Thursday, which allowed to advance in the consolidation of perimeters and to avoid reproductions.
This helped the Jarilla fire (Extremadura) to be stabilized after eleven active days and affecting more than 17,000 hectares in a perimeter of 170 kilometers, the largest fire in recent history in that region.
Although this Friday there is a slight rise in temperatures in Spain, "no significant gusts of wind are expected, so that the workers should be progressing favorably," said the undersecretary of the Ministry of the Interior, Susana Crisóstomo.
As for the state means employed, all the forest brigades of the Ministry for Ecological Transition and Demographic Challenge continue to operate supported by 45 aerial means that carry out daily unloading missions. The Military Emergency Unit maintains the deployment of 1,400 troops, supported by another 1,000 military personnel from other units of the three armies.
The National Police and the Civil Guard "maintain their average deployment of the last days", focused on the protection of the confined populations and on evacuation (decreasing) and relocation (increasing) in points free of risk. Since the beginning of the pre-emergency phase, more than 33,000 people have been evacuated.

urn:contentItem:6GP5-34K3-RS6W-73K2-00000-00VIDEO: Biggest Langley Good Times Cruise-in went smoothly2025-09-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:50:23ZLexisNexisVIDEO: Biggest Langley Good Times Cruise-in went smoothly

As Jason Molden was driving his '72 Monte Carlo from his home in Strathcona County, Alberta to Aldergrove, he found out there was a forest fire in his way.

"Fortunately I got a tip from a friend saying, hey, the road was closed," Molden recounted. "I diverted around. I think [the new route] went down Hwy. 24. What a gorgeous highway that was."

It was Saturday, the day of the show, and Molden had parked his car on Fraser Hwy., with a miniature, custom-made slot car track running laps in his engine compartment. Molden's was one of about 1,300 vehicles on display at Canada's largest charity car show.

Cruise-In president Riccardo Sestito said it was the biggest turnout for the annual show since it moved to Aldergrove, and it went well.

"It was the smoothest one yet," Sestito commented.

"There were no incidents."

Sestito said requiring everyone to pre-register worked out well, and he thinks the practice should continue.

"They came and they had their spots and everything was done. First time we've done that, it worked out well, so I think that's the future."

Organizers were able to find extra parking along 265A St., and at the Aldergrove community centre which has extra space now that the KFC is gone – and by limiting the number of sponsors.

Cruise-In treasurer Brianne Kindzersky explained.

"We had to park people on Old Yale and they did not like that at all," Kindzersky said. "So we knew that we needed more space in on Fraser so that we could fit all the cars. So we limited the number of sponsors that we had this year to prioritize the vehicles. Because we had a limited number of sponsors they did step up with bigger donations."

An estimated 90,000 to 100,000 spectators turned out for the 28th Langley Good Times Cruise-In.

Hundreds waited in line at the In-N-Out food truck for a taste of the well-regarded chain's burgers.

Aldergrove residents Kevin and Misty Busch, who live about five minutes away, was first in line.

"We came bright and early when the sun wasn't shining," Kevin said.

Kevin, who described himself as a "die-hard In-N-Out fan" said when Misty had a look early in the morning, she discovered no-one was in the line-up.

"In-N-Out Burger is a great company that donates 100 per cent of their proceeds to this charity [Cruisie-in]," Kevin noted.

"[They have a] great history, family-run business. We're huge fans. Been to many locations across the U.S."

By the time the truck was getting ready to start serving, hundreds had lined up behind the couple.

Luis Hernandez, In-N-Out manager of special foreign events described it as "our annual cookout event," the only Canadian destination for the chain's community events food truck.

"We've been doing it for many years and there are loyal customers in front of me that have been waiting since 1 a.m., so we're super grateful for that."

One of the biggest car clubs at the event, the B.C. Hot Rod Association, arrived with 70 cars, and t-shirts and caps to sell.

BCHRA director of membership Walter Wagner said they arrived about 6 a.m.

"We love to come here," Wagner said. "It's gonna be a great day and we get new members here."

Established since 1957, he said the club has 456 active members located in B.C, Alberta, Saskatchewan, Washington, Oregon, and California.

Jodi Steeves, of the Aldergrove Business Association, who went with a fifties diner look for the ABA booth, said the annual show is, by and large, a boon to the local business community.

"It does bring a lot of money to the community," Steeves remarked.

"I know some business do get hurt a little bit by being having to be closed or Fraser Highway being closed, but a lot of business do do very well."

Jim McGregor, who wasn't sure exactly how may years, he's been M.C. at the main stage, was explaining the timeless appeal of Elvis Eite, Steve Ellliott, who did three shows.

"He draws a good crowd every time he sings," McGregor commented. "And nobody ever gets tired of the old classic Elvis music."

Over the years, the all-volunteer car show has collected nearly $2 million for local charities.

In 2024 alone, the Cruise-In society raised $94,000.

More information is available at Langley Good Times Cruise-In.

urn:contentItem:6GNB-4G53-RTR1-61SP-00000-00Emergencies asks the police to investigate the hidden camera at the fire station in Yátova.2025-09-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:50:23ZLexisNexisEmergencies asks the police to investigate the hidden camera at the fire station in Yátova.


The Department of Emergencies and Interior has asked the Police of the Generalitat to investigate the placement of a hidden camera in the forest fire unit of Yàtova, in a building of the regional government, as confirmed by sources of the department headed by Juan Carlos Valderrama.


After the discovery, the staff filed a complaint with the Guardia Civil and from the direction of the Valencian Society of Integral Management of Emergency Services (SGISE) has opened a file to conduct an internal investigation.
This has been indicated by sources in this department after the information advanced by elDiario.es, which reveals Wednesday that the hidden camera was located a couple of weeks ago in one of the offices of the unit of Buñol, whose base is in Yátova.
Given this information, the deputy spokeswoman of Compromís in the Corts Valencianes, Isaura Navarro, has pointed out that these are "very worrying facts that recall recent precedents in Spanish politics" and stressed the circumstance that the Buñol forest firefighters unit is the one that was removed from the Poyo ravine last October 29 during the dana.
The Sociedad Valenciana de Gestión Integral de los Servicios de Emergencias has opened a file to investigate the situation.
"It is alarming that in a context where there are still so many unknowns about the management of the Consell del PP in the catastrophe of October 29, appear elements such as this hidden camera, precisely in the unit that guarded the ravine of Poyo", has indicated, and has slipped that "who is afraid to know the truth about why the withdrawal of these firefighters was ordered, leaving without key information in the coordination centers, is who else may be tempted to use any method to control the information".
The deputy spokeswoman stressed that "recently, under right-wing governments, there have been cases of illegal espionage against the opposition, such as the maneuvers of the so-called 'patriotic police', a case for which a judicial process is open with the top of the Ministry of the Interior of the Rajoy government charged".
"These precedents make us be alert to any hint of dirty games that seek to silence the truth and protect partisan interests that only serve to erode confidence in the institutions. From Compromís we demand a thorough and independent investigation to clarify the facts, and that the Consell assumes its responsibilities in the disastrous management of the dana," he concluded.
For its part, the Socialist spokeswoman for Emergencies in the Corts Valencianes, Alicia Andújar, said in a statement that this is "a very serious fact that violates the rights of workers" and has described as "urgent explanations". The Socialists denounce "mafia practices" of the Generalitat with forest firefighters and request the appearance of Valderrama in the regional chamber to give explanations of the facts.
The PSPV denounces "mafia-like practices" of the Generalitat with forest firefighters
"The Valencians do not deserve to have an autonomous government that belittles public workers in this way and that is more concerned about how to violate their rights than to improve their working conditions," said Andújar, who also highlighted the revelation that the hidden camera was found "at the base of the firefighters who were ordered to stop monitoring the Poyo ravine the day of the dana preventing them from controlling its flood and protecting the public. "A decision that remains unclear who took it," he added.
For the deputy, "this type of situation against the rights of public workers is not the first time since Mazón is 'president' of the Generalitat" and stressed that in February "and leaked to the media a private and manipulated conversation between two technicians of 112 and the Aemet, which was disseminated by Mazón and the PP, to imply that the Generalitat had no information about what was happening on October 29 in the province of Valencia and that is already being investigated."

urn:contentItem:6GBD-TDP3-RWCS-S38C-00000-00PARLIAMENT QUESTION: SATELLITES LAUNCHED BY ISRO2025-07-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:50:23ZLexisNexisPARLIAMENT QUESTION: SATELLITES LAUNCHED BY ISROStates News ServiceNEW DELHI, India

The following information was released by the Government of India:

by PIB Delhi

Details:

Post the announcement of space sector reforms in 2020, the number of registered space start-ups has grown exponentially to over 300.

IN-SPACe has facilitated two successful sub-orbital flights from Indian space start-ups in November 2022 and May 2024 respectively. Additionally, Six Non-Governmental Entities (NGEs) have launched fourteen satellites into orbit, demonstrating their capabilities.

Another parameter to gauge the impact of space sector reforms is by the number of proposals submitted for facilitation and authorization. IN-SPACe has received a total 658 applications from more than 380 NGEs for various activities. This support extended in Launch Vehicles and subsystem (89), Satellite launch and Subsystems (236), Ground Segment (43), Space applications (124), Promotional and Design Lab activities (121) and etc. as on 31st March, 2025.

IN-SPACe has issued 77 authorizations, signed 79 MoUs, issued 59 registration certificates to 3l data disseminators, signed 91 Joint Project Implementation Plans (JPIPs), and 79 transfer of technology agreements post Space Sector Reforms as on 31st March 2025.

Satellite data is used for enabling food security by generating multiple forecasts of crop production for major crops, towards informed decisions on stock and price management and export/ import policy decisions.

Satellite data is used for generating crop and location specific weather based agro advisories for income enhancement of farming community, under the Gramin Krishi Mausam Seva (GKMS). Mapping of Kharif rice fallows helped crop intensification in 6 eastern states (Odisha, Jharkhand, Bihar, Chhattisgarh, Assam and West Bengal), under National Food Security Mission.

Semi-physical yield model developed by ISRO for rice and wheat using space technology inputs has been selected as part of the suite of models of YES-TECH programme under PMFBY, Ministry of Agriculture and Farmers Welfare (MoAFW). The yield model developed by ISRO is being operationally rolled out for faster and transparent claim settlements of farmers in 9 states.

Satellite data is used in the hazard; vulnerability; risk (HVR) assessment, disaster monitoring, damage assessment, and development of early warning systems for major disasters such as flood, cyclones, landslide, earthquakes and forest fire. The space-based disaster specific products are being used by MHA, NDMA, State DMS organisations, and NDRF.

Flood inundation is being mapped for major floods every year (in 16 States during 2024) using satellite data, and the maps help the state nodal organisations for effective flood disaster management. Flood Hazard Zonation atlases have been developed using historical satellite-derived flood data since 1998 for several major flood-prone states, including Assam, Bihar, Uttar Pradesh, West Bengal, Odisha, and Andhra Pradesh. These serve as non-structural input for flood hazard mitigation and for developmental planning.

As part of the National Hydrology Project, ISRO developed spatial flood early warning systems for Godavari and Tapi Rivers, and are being run operationally since 2022. It helps decision making on flood hazard mitigation, including evacuation planning.

Active forest fires are detected using satellite data daily 6 to 8 times during the Indian forest fire season, and is ongoing for the fire season in 2025 also. This input helps the State Forest Departments for taking risk management measures.

As part of approval received from Government for Gaganyaan follow-on Missions Leading to Precursor for Bharatiya Antariksh Station (BAS) Revision in Gaganyaan Programme on 9th October 2024, a second manned mission - H2 will follow first crewed mission H1.

2nd crewed mission is targeted after the accomplishment of 1st crewed mission. Since the 2nd crewed mission is similar to 1st crewed mission, existing collaborations with various agencies is expected to continue.

This information was given by Dr. Jitendra Singh, Union Minister of State (Independent Charge) for Science and Technology, Minister of State (Independent Charge) for Earth Sciences, MoS PMO, Department of Atomic Energy and Department of Space, MoS Personnel, Public Grievances and Pensions, in a written reply in the Rajya Sabha today.

urn:contentItem:6FPH-KT43-RWH5-F0R6-00000-00New Findings from Metropolitan University of Technology Describe Advances in Technology (Deep Reinforcement Learning for Optimal Firebreak Placement In Forest Fire Prevention)2025-05-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:50:23ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGYNew Findings from Metropolitan University of Technology Describe Advances in Technology (Deep Reinforcement Learning for Optimal Firebreak Placement In Forest Fire Prevention)


2025 MAY 01 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Tech Daily News -- Investigators publish new report on Technology. According to news reporting from Santiago, Chile, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "The increasing frequency and intensity of large wildfires have become a significant natural hazard, requiring the development of advanced decision-support tools for resilient landscape design. Existing methods, such as Mixed Integer Programming and Stochastic Optimization, while effective, are computationally demanding."


Funders for this research include Competition for Research Regular Projects, Universidad Tecnologica Metropolitana, European Union (EU), CONICYT FONDECYT, ANID PIA/PUENTE, ANID/Fondecyt project.
The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from the Metropolitan University of Technology, "In this study, we introduce a novel Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) methodology to optimize the strategic placement of firebreaks across diverse landscapes. We employ Deep Q-Learning, Double Deep Q-Learning, and Dueling Double Deep Q-Learning, integrated with the Cell2Fire fire spread simulator and Convolutional Neural Networks. Our DRL agent successfully learns optimal firebreak locations, demonstrating superior performance compared to heuristics, especially after incorporating a pre-training loop. This improvement ranges between 1.59%-1.7% with respect to the heuristic, depending on the size of the instance, and 4.79%-6.81% when compared to a random solution. Our results highlight the potential of DRL for fire prevention, showing convergence with favorable results in cases as large as 40 x 40 cells."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "This study represents a pioneering application of reinforcement learning to fire prevention and landscape management."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Optimal Firebreak Placement In Forest Fire Prevention. Applied Soft Computing, 2025;175. Applied Soft Computing can be contacted at: Elsevier, Radarweg 29, 1043 Nx Amsterdam, Netherlands. (Elsevier - www.elsevier.com; Applied Soft Computing - www.journals.elsevier.com/applied-soft-computing/)
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Jaime Carrasco-Barra, Metropolitan University of Technology, Fac Ingn, Dept. of Industrial, Santiago, Chile. Additional authors for this research include Lucas Murray, Tatiana Castillo, Richard Weber, Andres Weintraub, Isaac Martin de Diego, Jose Ramon Gonzalez-Olabarria and Jordi Garcia-Gonzalo.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.asoc.2025.113043. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

urn:contentItem:6GM4-3XW3-RV3T-534G-00000-00Researchers at Indian Institute of Science Report New Data on Machine Learning (Automl-fire: Automated Machine-learning Approach To Predict Forest Fires)2025-08-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:50:23ZLexisNexisMACHINE LEARNINGResearchers at Indian Institute of Science Report New Data on Machine Learning (Automl-fire: Automated Machine-learning Approach To Predict Forest Fires)


2025 AUG 29 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Robotics & Machine Learning Daily News Daily News -- Fresh data on Machine Learning are presented in a new report. According to news reporting out of Madhya Pradesh, India, by NewsRx editors, research stated, "Forest fires pose a serious threat to the environment. Their frequency and intensity have increased in recent decades due to climate change and heightened anthropogenic interference."


Financial support for this research came from Department of Science and Technology (DST) , Government of India, for INSPIRE-SHE (Scholarship for Higher Education).
Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from the Indian Institute of Science, "About 21.7% of India's total land is covered by forests, which play a crucial role in biodiversity, ecology, and the livelihoods dependent on these ecosystems. However, 36% of these forested regions are prone to frequent and devastating fire. Given this vulnerability, predicting forest fires is essential for minimising damage. In this first pan-India study, we predict the forest fire occurrence in the most vulnerable regions across India using a dataset spanning from 2003 to 2018, incorporating variables such as cloud cover, elevation, forest cover fraction, humidity, NDVI, population, soil moisture, temperature, wind speed, and precipitation. We partitioned the data into four clusters based on spatial proximity to capture regional patterns. SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) values were utilised to enhance model interpretability and provide insights into socio-technical complexities unique to different regions. We analysed the Partial Dependence Plots (PDP) to capture the trend of forest fires with individual features. The challenge of data imbalance, often encountered in natural hazard prediction, was addressed using the Synthetic Minority Over-Sampling Technique for Regression with Gaussian Noise (SMOGN) algorithm, which balances regression data. Selecting appropriate machine-learning models and adeptly tuning their hyperparameters is a complex process that requires domain expertise. To address this, we proposed an automated machine-learning (AutoML) framework that utilises Bayesian optimisation to return a best-performing, finely-tuned model. The 'AutoML-FIRE' model exhibited robust performance, with R values between 0.73 and 0.85 and RMSE values ranging from 3.40 to 6.09, outperforming all considered benchmarking algorithms. Furthermore, uncertainty analysis and spatial distribution analysis were conducted to validate the model's stability."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Our analysis demonstrates that the AutoML-FIRE model is robust, exhibits broad applicability for national-scale fire risk assessment, and enables notifications to authorities and local communities regarding impending fire events."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Automl-fire: Automated Machine-learning Approach To Predict Forest Fires. Environmental Modelling & Software, 2025;193. Environmental Modelling & Software can be contacted at: Elsevier Sci Ltd, 125 London Wall, London, England. (Elsevier - www.elsevier.com; Environmental Modelling & Software - www.journals.elsevier.com/environmental-modelling-and-software/)
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Abhilash Singh, Indian Institute of Science Educ & Res Bhopal, Dept. of Earth and Environmental Sciences, Fluvial Geomorphol & Remote Sensing Lab, Bypass Rd, Bhopal 462066, Madhya Pradesh, India. Additional authors for this research include Saurabh Toraskar, Adil Khan, M. Niranjannaik and Kumar Gaurav Fluvial.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.envsoft.2025.106578. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

urn:contentItem:6GM8-88P3-RXCR-B0PT-00000-00VIDEO: The King and Queen of Spain thank the fire fighting services in Extremadura for their work2025-08-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:50:23ZLexisNexisVIDEO: The King and Queen of Spain thank the fire fighting services in Extremadura for their work


King Felipe VI and Queen Letizia continue their visit to Extremadura making a stop in Cabezabellosa where they have been received by more than 500 people in the town square, with applause and cheers thanking their visit and their support to those affected by the great fire of Jarilla that has devastated more than 17,400 hectares in the north of Cáceres.


Their Majesties have spent almost an hour greeting the residents of this town, the first to be evacuated along with Jarilla and Villar de Plasencia, on Tuesday, August 12, as well as members of the firefighting teams, with whom they have shared conversation to inquire about their experience in these days of fighting the fire.
Specifically, have been represented the UME, Army, Civil Guard, Civil Protection, National Parks, Infoex Plan, Tragsa, BRIF Pinofranqueado Miteco, Red Cross Extremadura, Firefighters of the Provincial Fire Fighting Service of Cáceres, 112, Local Police, Natural Environment Agents, Psychologists, social workers, Forest Fire Fighting Service of Andalusia, among others.
After the meeting with Their Majesties, Álvaro Hernández, who is the chief coordinator of the BRIF of Pinofranqueado, said that "it is a satisfaction that they themselves recognize the work that has been done by all the operatives who have been integrated in the extinction".
Work in a fire, the Jarilla, which has been the "largest" in which he has worked in Extremadura, which were "quite complicated days", where the flames almost reached the houses of this town, which caused "some tension, because in the end that you burn all your property, it hurts.
For his part, a member of the UME has stressed that the moments of combat against the flames are of "very high demand", and that in this case has been on the front line "as always, wherever we are requested".
He also stressed the importance of coordination between the different services involved in an extinction, where feelings of "dedication and combat risk, fire in this case, to restore normality to the environment" are experienced.
During her stay in this town, second stop of the visit of the King and Queen of Extremadura this Friday to the areas most affected by the fires, after her visit to Rebollar, Queen Letizia has received several gifts such as a pacifier and some flowers or a T-shirt with the flag of Extremadura that the neighbors of Cabezabellosa have given her. Their Majesties have signed in the book of honor of the town hall before continuing their tour.
The third and last stop of this trip through Extremadura will be in Hervás where they will meet with some of the mayors of the municipalities affected by the fire in these three regions of northern Cáceres Trasierra-Tierras de Granadilla, Valle del Ambroz and Valle del Jerte.
The King and Queen are accompanied by the Minister of the Interior, Fernando Grande-Marlaska; the President of the Regional Government of Extremadura, María Guardiola; the Government Delegate in the region, José Luis Quintana; the President of the Assembly, Blanca Martín; and the President of the Provincial Council of Cáceres, Miguel Ángel Morales, among other authorities.
Previously, during their meeting in Rebollar, the King and Queen took the opportunity to reiterate their gratitude not only to the security forces and the professionals of the fire-fighting services, but also to the neighbors, livestock farmers, farmers and people attached to the land for their dedication, collaboration and civic responsibility to overcome the critical situation experienced.
In addition, they have stressed the importance of addressing depopulation in rural areas as the settlement in the territory ensures better care of the environment.

urn:contentItem:6GM8-88F3-RX6H-21YP-00000-00CSIF urges Yolanda Díaz to apply early retirement and develop the catalog of diseases for forest firefighters2025-08-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:50:23ZLexisNexisCSIF urges Yolanda Díaz to apply early retirement and develop the catalog of diseases for forest firefighters


The second vice-president of the Government and Minister of Labor and Social Economy, Yolanda Díaz, met this Friday in Orense with union representatives to address the labor situation of the forest firefighters. After the meeting, Diaz has insisted on the need to "cover ratios", "improve coordination" between the various bodies and firefighting services, "improve their training" and focus on "prevention" throughout the year to deal with forest fires. Meanwhile, CSIF has demanded the adoption of measures of state competence pending implementation to improve the working conditions of the staff of the fire fighting devices, such as early retirement and occupational health protection of forest firefighters, environmental agents, technicians and other members of the firefighting teams.


The union warns that the Government can not continue to delay the implementation of laws already passed or the creation of the catalog of occupational diseases of a group that provides an essential public service against fires. CSIF valued positively the willingness to dialogue of the Government, but insisted that solutions must materialize immediately.
Among the measures proposed, CSIF stressed the need to effectively implement Law 5/2024, regarding the early retirement of forest firefighters through reduction coefficients. The union called on Yolanda Diaz to ensure that this regulation is fully in force next November, as established when it was approved in November 2024.
Also, CSIF demanded immediate progress in the development of Law 4/2024, which regulates the early retirement of civil servants in the group of environmental agents. The organization recalled that the rule set a deadline of three months for the constitution of the commission responsible for implementing this right, with no progress reported to date.
In relation to retirement, CSIF insisted that its implementation must ensure the inclusion of all groups involved, such as the Supramunicipal Emergency Groups (GES), avoiding any discrimination.
Another of the demands was the implementation of the catalog of occupational diseases of the group of forest fire departments, pending development despite the fact that the law that regulates it established a maximum period of one year for the responsible commission to approve it. CSIF reminded the minister that this is also a measure of state competence and that it cannot be postponed.
At the meeting, CSIF stressed that fire prevention and extinguishing services are an essential public service, so they must be provided exclusively by public employees and never through subcontracting to private companies.
The Central Union informed the vice-president of the measures proposed by this union to the government of the Xunta de Galicia, highlighting the reinforcement of the device and the hiring throughout the year of permanent staff discontinued.
For CSIF, the annual hiring is an urgent and necessary decision to strengthen the operational capacity of the service in a context of increasing risks associated with climate change. In addition, it is not only essential for the response in the months of greatest fire risk, but also to maintain the prevention work throughout the year and undertake the work of environmental restoration after fires, thus reducing their impact and preserving the Galician ecosystems.
This measure, which is a historical claim of the union, would directly affect about 1,000 forest firefighters, professionals who are a key piece in the defense of the Galician natural heritage. If this decision is not adopted, next November 17 is expected the dismissal of about 1,000 workers, which would mean an unaffordable loss for the firefighting operation and for the protection of the environment.
The union has also demanded the creation of 140 new posts in the technical scale of the SPIF, belonging to the specialty of Brigade Chief Forest Firefighter, which will double the number of operational brigades and ensure better coordination, prevention and response capacity to forest emergencies.

urn:contentItem:6GPW-CN43-RTS4-84V3-00000-00LIGHTNING TO SPARK MORE WILDFIRES IN WESTERN US IN COMING DECADES NEW STUDY FINDS INCREASING HOT WEATHER AND LIGHTNING COULD SPARK MORE FIRES2025-09-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:50:23ZLexisNexisLIGHTNING TO SPARK MORE WILDFIRES IN WESTERN US IN COMING DECADES NEW STUDY FINDS INCREASING HOT WEATHER AND LIGHTNING COULD SPARK MORE FIRESStates News ServiceWASHINGTON, DC

The following information was released by the American Geophysical Union:

Lightning will ignite more wildfires in the western United States in the coming decades as temperatures increase due to climate change, according to a new study that combined predictions for fire-friendly and lightning-friendly weather conditions.

In the western United States, lightning is responsible for more than two-thirds of the area burned by wildfires, and that number is only going to grow. Starting as early as 2031-2060, the study found essentially all of the western United States, or 98%, will see an increase in days posing a risk for lightning started wildfires.

Areas that are already at high risk for wildfires started by lightning, such as Oregon, Idaho and Montana, are expected to see the largest increase in overall lightning days, with up to 12 more days per summer by 2060. Some areas, particularly in the U.S. Southwest, like Arizona, are expected to see a smaller increase as they will simply see less lightning.

The new study was published in Earth's Future, AGU's journal for interdisciplinary research on the past, present and future of our planet and its inhabitants.

"The first step was to project lightning," said Dmitri Kalashnikov, research scientist at the University of California Merced and lead author on the study. "The typical climate models don't directly simulate lightning. It's too small a process."

To get around this, Kalashnikov created his own machine-learning models that predict lightning based on the occurrence of weather variables that are typically found in climate models, such as the amount of moisture in the atmosphere. He published the models last year in AGU's Journal of Geophysical Research: Atmospheres.

He combined his lightning models with the Fire Weather Index projections to predict the number of future days when conditions that encourage lightning and fire ignition and spread coincide.

The Canadian Forest Fire Weather Index, created in 1968, measures how favorable the weather is on a given day for wildfires. It keeps track of temperature, precipitation, humidity and other factors that could impact fires. For example, higher temperatures or lower precipitation, especially prolonged, can increase the chances of a fire.

While there have been previous models created for worldwide changes in lightning, Kalashnikov and his team created models that were specifically trained for locations in the western United States and for a closer timeframe. Their models focused on the years 2030 to 2060, compared to previous models that typically only looked at the end of the century.

Using the Fire Weather Index, researchers were able to predict how the number of days that have a high risk of wildfires will change over the coming decades.

The modeling found the northwestern United States was expected to see the largest increase in lightning days. Parts of Idaho, Oregon and Montana saw the largest increase in this cloud-to-ground lightning, or lightning that strikes the ground, which can ignite flammable vegetation. However, due to lesser increases in the Fire Weather Index, these areas will see slower increases in fire risk compared to areas farther south.

The southern half of the western United States still saw an increase in potential fires started by lightning, despite seeing a lower risk for lightning increases than the northern states. The increase is still projected because the entire West saw a general increase in high-risk days for wildfires as temperatures climb and the risk of droughts and heatwaves increase. In the south, Colorado, Wyoming, Arizona and New Mexico projected the largest increases in wildfires started by lightning.

Kalashnikov said next steps could expand what the models include, like bringing in rainfall amounts to differentiate between dry lightning and wet lightning, or lightning that happens with or without rain. This could help differentiate between thunderstorms that pose a risk of wildfires versus heavy-rain producing storms that could create flash flooding.

"You can't help but wonder what the future will look like, especially if you dig in and you realize that there's actually a lot that we don't understand," Kalashnikov said.

Notes for journalists:

This study is published in Earth's Future, an open-access AGU journal. View and download a pdf of the study here. Neither this press release nor the study is under embargo.

Paper title:

"Projections of Lightning-Ignited Wildfire Risk in the Western United States"

Authors:

Dmitri Kalashnikov, Sierra Nevada Research Institute, University of California, Merced, California, USA

John Abatzoglou, Management of Complex Systems Department, University of California, Merced, California, USA

Frances Davenport, Civil and Environmental Engineering, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, Colorado, USA

Zachary Labe, NOAA OAR Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Laboratory, Princeton, New Jersey, USA

Paul Loikith, Department of Geography, Portland State University, Portland, Oregon, USA

Danielle Touma, Institute for Geophysics, University of Texas, Austin, Texas, USA

urn:contentItem:6GM8-88C3-RWV2-G40X-00000-00Castilla y León ignored requests from forestry agents to return from vacation at the beginning of the emergency.2025-08-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:50:23ZLexisNexisCastilla y León ignored requests from forestry agents to return from vacation at the beginning of the emergency.


The Junta de Castilla y León ignored at the beginning of the fire emergency at least six proposals from forestry agents who offered to cancel their vacations and collaborate in extinguishing the fires, according to one of the requests they have shown to EL PAÍS. The offers, according to the rangers, received no response. "There were personnel who were with the family in villages watching everything burn," says one of them.


One of the agents explains that he wanted to travel from his province to León to collaborate. For this reason, he registered a formal request, to which he did not receive a response. Other colleagues did so verbally, but they were not called to work either. Several days later, on August 17, as published by eldiario.es, the General Directorate of Natural Heritage and Forestry Policy sent a message to the heads of service demanding "urgently" that the personnel on vacation or rest be called to rejoin the bases.
The Castilian and Leonese president, Alfonso Fernandez Mañueco, had assured that week that the Board had "sufficient means" and "the problem" was not "of the operatives or lack of means" but of the "exceptional meteorological circumstances". The Ministry of Environment has branded the requests of the forest rangers to suspend their vacations as a "hoax" despite the fact that they are in writing.
Internal reports
The regional Forest Fire Planning and Analysis Unit warned at least since August 1 of the impending heat wave and the "high" or "very high" levels of probability of ignition and spread. This newspaper has accessed the daily bulletins prepared by technicians of the Regional Ministry between August 1 and 23 where they predicted the risk. As an example, the report of August 1 predicted a "notable increase in temperatures for next week with AEMET [Spanish Meteorological Agency] warning for heat wave" and predicted a "very high-extreme" fire risk. "Rapid spreads associated with intense winds are expected. Strong initial dispatches are recommended," they state.
Upon learning of these reports, the Ministry of Environment decided on August 1 to apply the alert for meteorological risk of forest fires for the following week, which means the prohibition of maintenance work in forests. As the days went by, the reports emphasized that the risk increased as the humidity decreased and the heat increased on the overgrown vegetation after the rainy spring. Despite the risk, some firefighters denounce that there were "crews belonging to subcontractors" who maintained these works in the forests.
The report of August 8, the date on which the first fire was declared in El Bierzo (León) -one day later the Yeres fire was declared, which burned the World Heritage Site of Las Médulas-, stated: "The probability of ignition will be at very high levels and the rate of spread at very high levels". They also predicted "extremely low humidity" and no precipitation on dry fuel (vegetation). The forecasts were correct and that weekend the crisis broke out, with large fires in León and Zamora.
The bulletins, of about 10 pages each, compile the number of active fires each day, the declared outbreaks, the previous day, a summary of the expected meteorology and the fire danger for the next hours, as well as the atmospheric situation or radiosondes. They also include several maps on air masses and their movements, wind gusts, temperatures and maximum and minimum humidity, temperature anomalies, accumulated and expected precipitation, probability of ignition and several parameters on fires. In spite of the risks warned by the reports known by the Junta since August 1, numerous fire departments have criticized that there were hardly any means at the beginning of many of the fires declared in Castilla y León.
