urn:contentItem:6GN9-MC23-RYTH-N1CW-00000-00Spain reports nearly 400,000 hectares burned and 37 arrests due to fires2025-08-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:50:23ZLexisNexisSpain reports nearly 400,000 hectares burned and 37 arrests due to fires

Spain continues to tackle several major wildfires in one of the country's most destructive fire seasons in recent decades, despite temperatures dropping across the Iberian Peninsula.

The humid weather and rainfall have provided some relief to Spanish authorities in their fight against the fires that have been ravaging much of the country for weeks, at a time when more than 391,000 hectares have already been burned so far this year, according to data from the European Forest Fire Information System.

Although 40 fires are still active across the country, recent rain, especially in the province of León, could help firefighters control the situation there, allowing authorities to focus their efforts on other areas.

On Wednesday, the president of the Castile and León region, Alfonso Fernández Mañueco, said that firefighting efforts are progressing favourably thanks to improved weather conditions.

Mañueco also presented an aid plan for those affected, which includes €500 in aid for those who have had to evacuate their homes and up to €185,000 for those who have lost their homes to the flames.

The situation in Castile and León is progressing "significantly" and favourably, as indicated by the president of the autonomous community, partly thanks to the change in weather conditions, which have improved significantly.

"Conditions are favourable and significant progress is being made in extinguishing the fire," Mañueco reported, emphasising that "when circumstances allow, the operation works effectively."

Fires in Galicia have ravaged small, sparsely populated towns, forcing locals in many cases to step in before firefighters arrive.

Firefighting units from Germany arrived in northern Spain on Tuesday to help fight the blazes, Spain's Interior Ministry announced. More than 20 vehicles were deployed to help fight an ongoing blaze in Jarilla in the Extremadura region that borders Portugal, the ministry said.

Residents battle a wildfire advancing toward Rebordondo village, near Ourense, in northwestern Spain, on Monday, Aug. 18, 2025. AP Photo/Pablo Garcia

In Galicia, land management has also played a role. Large stretches of unmanaged vegetation and depopulated villages in forested land have led to the buildup of wildfire fuel, said Adrian Regos, an ecologist at the Biological Mission of Galicia, a research institute.

Air quality deteriorated across large parts of Spain over the past week as a result of the wildfires, data from the EU’s Copernicus climate monitoring agency showed. Smoke from the Iberian Peninsula fires reached France, the UK, and Scandinavia, it said.

Several fires have been caused by human activity. Police have detained 37 people for suspected arson and are investigating 89 more, Spain's Civil Guard said Tuesday.

In Portugal, more than 3,700 firefighters were tackling blazes, including four major ones in the north and centre.

Wildfires there have burned about 235,000 hectares, according to EFFIS — nearly five times more than the 2006-2024 average for this period. Two people there have died.

Europe has been warming twice as fast as the global average since the 1980s, according to Copernicus. Scientists say that climate change is exacerbating the frequency and intensity of heat and dryness in parts of Europe, making the region more vulnerable to wildfires.

Al Jazeera and news agencies

August 15th, 2025 ( Al Jazeera English - Delivered by Newstex )

Firefighters in Spain, Portugal and Greece are battling fierce wildfires as scorching, dry, intense heat fuels blazes across the region, coinciding with major religious holidays, as global warming leaves its mark on Europe.

Spain faced 14 major fires on Friday, said Virginia Barcones, the emergency services chief, as temperatures were forecast to rise further over the weekend.

'Today will once again be a very tough day with an extreme risk of new fires,' Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez warned on Friday.

The State Meteorological Agency placed most of the country under extreme fire danger alerts, particularly in the north and west, where the largest blazes raged. The current heatwave, with temperatures topping 40 degrees Celsius (104 degrees Fahrenheit) on several days this month, is expected to linger until Monday.

In Galicia, fires shut down several highways and halted high-speed rail services to Madrid. The EU's European Forest Fire Information System reported that wildfires in Spain this year have already burned 158,000 hectares (390,000 acres), an area the size of metropolitan London.

Friday marked the Feast of the Assumption in Spain and Portugal, a major Catholic holiday usually observed with family gatherings and processions. In Portugal, almost 4,000 firefighters battled seven active fires, as authorities extended a state of alert until Sunday. The government also sought European Union assistance under its civil protection mechanism.

A day earlier, Spain received two Canadair water bomber aircraft from the European Union, the first time it had ever activated the bloc's emergency firefighting aid.

Elsewhere in Southern Europe, Greece continued to struggle with a major wildfire burning for four days on the island of Chios. Several overnight evacuations took place as flames spread through the island's northern region. Two planes and two helicopters dropped water during calmer winds early on Friday.

After devastating fires earlier this week in western Greece, the fire service remained on high alert outside Athens and in southern areas, where strong winds and high temperatures heightened the danger.

Across the Balkans and Southern Europe, demand for the EU's shared firefighting resources has soared this year. Bulgaria, Montenegro and Albania have all called for help in recent days as the system has already been deployed as often as during the whole of last year's fire season.

Ecumenical Patriarch Bartholomew, the spiritual head of the world's Orthodox Christians, expressed solidarity with wildfire victims during prayers for the Dormition of the Virgin Mary, one of the faith's most significant feast days.

SECTION 2 CORPORATE PROFILE AND INDEPENDENT RATINGS

2.1 Activities

Weyerhaeuser Company, headquartered in Seattle, Washington, is one of the largest private owners of timberlands in the world, with a history dating back to 1900. Its core business activities center on sustainable forest management, timber harvesting, and the production of wood products. The company''s largest sources of revenue come from its Timberlands segment, which includes the sale of logs and timber, and its Wood Products segment, which manufactures and distributes lumber, engineered wood, and other building materials primarily for residential and commercial construction. Additionally, Weyerhaeuser operates a Real Estate, Energy, and Natural Resources segment, focusing on land sales and renewable energy opportunities. Among its business lines, the Wood Products segment has shown notable growth, driven by strong demand in the housing and construction markets. With a commitment to environmental stewardship, Weyerhaeuser continues to balance profitability with sustainable practices across its extensive land holdings. It is the NYSE's 5th largest Building materials & fixtures company by market capitalisation.

In FY 2024, the top earner of Revenue was WOOD PRODUCTS [68%] followed by TIMBERLANDS [26.9%] at Rank 2 and REAL ESTATE & ENR [5.1%] at Rank 3. In FY 2024, revenue growth was highest in REAL ESTATE & ENR [7.7%] .

October 30: Weyerhaeuser Provides Update on Timberlands Portfolio Optimization Actions

Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) today announced updates on recent actions to enhance portfolio quality and value through a series of strategic and capital-efficient timberland transactions. In the third quarter, the company completed two high-quality acquisitions totaling $459 million, including its previously announced transaction for timberlands in North Carolina and Virginia. Additionally, in the third quarter Weyerhaeuser advanced three divestiture packages of non-core timberlands - two of which were closed or under contract in early October, totaling $410 million of expected cash proceeds by year end. The company anticipates the third divestiture to close in early 2026, with total proceeds from all divestitures expected to exceed the cash outlay required for its recently completed acquisitions.

"These transactions represent strategic opportunities to recycle capital in a tax-efficient manner to further optimize and improve our timberlands portfolio," says Devin W. Stockfish, president and chief executive officer. "As we've demonstrated over the last several years, we are committed to active portfolio management across our timber holdings and have remained disciplined and nimble in our approach to growing the quality and value of our timberlands. Through this process, we've achieved the multi-year growth target we announced in September 2021 - and by early 2026, we will have offset a significant portion of our acquisitions with divestitures of non-core acreage. Over a similar period, we've also returned a substantial amount of cash back to shareholders through dividends and share repurchase and announced a compelling engineered wood products growth opportunity - all while maintaining a strong balance sheet. Looking forward, we will continue to evaluate capital-efficient opportunities that enhance the return profile of our timberlands, while also balancing other levers across our capital allocation framework to drive superior long-term value for our shareholders."

Summary of Acquisitions

Unique, off-market transactions featuring high-quality and strategically located acreage with portfolio-leading timber and financial attributes in their respective regions.

Acquired at a combined timber-only Adjusted EBITDA multiple of 21x1.

May 28: Weyerhaeuser, Firefighter Behavioral Health Alliance Partner for Fourth Year to Provide Mental Health Resources for Wildland Firefighters

Fighting Fires Together campaign raises awareness and helps address mental health challenges of wildland firefighting

SEATTLE, May 28, 2025- Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) and Firefighter Behavioral Health Alliance (FBHA) today announced an extension of their Fighting Fires Together campaign, a partnership that provides specialized mental health support for wildland firefighters and their families across the Pacific Northwest.

Fighting Fires Together, now in its fourth year, addresses the often-overlooked mental health impacts of wildland firefighting in isolated, hazardous and highly stressful conditions. Through a free online resource hub, first responders can find specially designed content, including videos about Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), depression, anxiety and suicide prevention, along with mental health tips, educational articles and contacts for occupationally aware support groups and counselors in Oregon, Washington and British Columbia.

Weyerhaeuser's support for wildland firefighting efforts in the Pacific Northwest began in the aftermath of the Yacolt Burn in 1902, when the company began advocating for Washington's first forest fire legislation and the funding of community fire prevention education and patrols. Today, as Weyerhaeuser celebrates its 125th anniversary, the company continues to play an active role in fire prevention and response through its forest management operations. Weyerhaeuser employees and contractors receive annual fire readiness training, build fire breaks and containment lines, conduct aerial surveys and deploy tanker trucks, helicopters and quick-response crews to wildland fires.

"After launching the Fighting Fires Together campaign with FBHA four years ago, we're proud to continue this effort to support wildland firefighters and their mental health as they work in challenging conditions to protect our communities," says Bill Frings, vice president of Western Timberlands for Weyerhaeuser.

SEATTLE, May 21, 2025 - Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) today announced it has reached an agreement to sell its lumber mill in Princeton, British Columbia, to the Gorman Group, owners of Gorman Bros.Lumber Ltd., a family-owned wood products manufacturer headquartered in West Kelowna, B.C. The purchase price is approximately $120 million CAD in cash, which includes Weyerhaeuser's manufacturing facility, all associated timber license assets in British Columbia and the value of working capital, which will be subject to customary purchase price adjustments at closing.

Weyerhaeuser and Gorman Group have a long-standing relationship in Canada. Gorman Bros.Lumber is currently the Princeton mill's largest customer, and Gorman Group has operated in Canada for more than 75 years, with offices and facilities in B.C. and Washington state.

"We are grateful to all the dedicated employees who contributed to the success of our Princeton operations over the years," says Devin W. Stockfish, president and chief executive officer for Weyerhaeuser. "The community has always been incredibly welcoming and supportive of our mill and people, and it was important for us to sell to a local buyer with deep roots in the region. Gorman has been a great customer and strategic partner, and we believe this will be a seamless transition that will position the mill for future success in a challenging operating environment - providing long-term certainty for the mill and the broader community."

"Weyerhaeuser's Princeton operation will be a natural fit with the Gorman Group," says Nick Arkle, chief executive officer of the Gorman Group. "We've had a strong connection to the Princeton operation for many years, and we know firsthand the skill, commitment and quality that define its team.

ECONOMIC AND MARKET CONDITIONS AFFECTING OUR OPERATIONS

Our market conditions and the strength of the broader U.S. economy are, and will continue to be, influenced by the trajectory of activity in the U.S. housing and repair and remodel segments, inflation trends and interest rates. The demand for sawlogs within our Timberlands segment is directly affected by domestic production of wood-based building products. The strength of the U.S. housing market, particularly new residential construction, strongly affects demand in our Wood Products segment, as does repair and remodeling activity. Seasonal weather patterns impact the level of construction activity in the U.S., which in turn affects demand for our logs and wood products. Our Timberlands segment, specifically the Western region, is also affected by export demand and trade policy. Japanese housing starts are a key driver of export log demand in Japan. The demand for pulpwood from our Timberlands segment is directly affected by the production of pulp, paper and oriented strand board (OSB), as well as the demand for biofuels, such as wood-burning pellets made from pulpwood. Our Timberlands segment is also influenced by the availability of harvestable timber. SECTION 5 WEYERHAEUSER 10-Q: 12 CONSEQUENTIAL MANAGEMENT DECISIONS

Strategic Expansion of Engineered Wood Products Capacity

Management has committed $500 million to constructing a new TimberStrand facility in Monticello, Arkansas, beginning in 2025, with operations expected by 2027. This investment is projected to expand engineered wood products capacity by 10 million cubic feet, positioning Weyerhaeuser to seize greater market share in the growing housing sector. While the long-term growth and revenue potential align with favorable housing trends, the funding approach-whether via existing cash or external financing-could pressure short-term liquidity or increase debt levels.

Shareholder Value Enhancement Through New $1 Billion Buyback Program

Following completion of a prior program, management authorized a new $1 billion share repurchase initiative in May 2025. This move underscores confidence in company valuation and enhances earnings per share by reducing outstanding shares. While the initiative aligns with the shareholder return framework targeting 75-80% of Adjusted FAD, it reflects a strategic trade-off by potentially limiting capital allocation flexibility during potential market volatility.

Maintaining Dividend Stability Amid Economic Challenges

Weyerhaeuser continues its cash dividend framework, targeting a 75-80% payout of Adjusted FAD, and has paid $304 million in 2025 dividends thus far. The year-to-date payout decline-due primarily to an absence of supplemental dividends in Q1-highlights the company's adaptability to fluctuating cash flows. For income-focused investors, this consistent dividend policy provides predictability, though variability in Adjusted FAD may influence future distributions.

Strengthened Liquidity with an Updated Credit Facility

The company amended and restated its revolving credit facility in June 2025, increasing capacity to $1.75 billion and extending maturity to 2030. This ensures access to substantial liquidity without current borrowings, providing operational flexibility while reducing refinancing risks during economic uncertainty. The alignment of covenant compliance further supports Weyerhaeuser's credit profile.

Capital Optimization through Debt Repayment and Refinancing

Management refinanced maturing debt by repaying $210 million in debentures while issuing a $300 million senior unsecured term loan maturing in 2030. This strategic action reduced the weighted average interest rate, trimming interest expense by $2 million year-to-date, while preserving $592 million in cash and full credit availability. For investors, this showcases disciplined capital allocation, though possible fluctuations in interest rates remain a key consideration.

Focused Capital Investments to Drive Operational Efficiency

Excluding the Monticello project, management outlined $400 million in planned 2025 capital expenditures, with $200 million deployed so far. This includes both Timberland and Wood Products maintenance expansions designed to sustain production efficiency. Despite a year-over-year increase, such investments affirm a long-term strategy to sharpen competitiveness-though revenue pressure could strain cash flow in adverse market conditions.

Expansion into Carbon Markets to Capture Sustainability Growth

Weyerhaeuser progresses in leveraging its natural climate solutions, capitalizing on the growing demand for carbon credits and renewable energy. By positioning itself within key sustainability sectors, management aims to unlock new revenue streams while aligning with global decarbonization goals. Though regulatory adjustments and market development require monitoring, this initiative offers potential upside for forward-looking investors.

Unlocking Value Through Strategic Divestitures

The announced sale of a wood products manufacturing facility (pending regulatory approvals) reflects Weyerhaeuser's strategy to streamline operations and optimize its asset base. If successful, this move could free up cash for reinvestment in higher-margin opportunities and improve overall profitability. However, pending closures introduce timing uncertainties for short-term financial performance.

Timberland Acquisition to Strengthen Strategic Resource Base

Management advanced a timberland acquisition that remains subject to regulatory approval. This investment supports long-term timber supply needs for the Timberlands segment while positioning the company in tightening log markets. The targeted synergies enhance revenue potential, though integration risks and upfront costs require careful oversight.

Operational Efficiency Improvements Amid Inflationary Pressures

Initiatives to restructure manufacturing processes and reduce costs address inflation-driven challenges related to raw materials, energy, and labor. By improving cost structures, Weyerhaeuser aims to mitigate margin compression and enhance profitability. Successful implementation will be key, especially given labor market constraints influencing production continuity.

Proactive Risk Management for Contingent Liabilities

Reserves for litigation and environmental responsibilities demonstrate management's financial diligence in safeguarding against operational uncertainties. By maintaining adequate coverage for contingent liabilities, Weyerhaeuser bolsters its balance sheet resilience. However, potential over-reserving may tie up capital unnecessarily and requires vigilant management assessment.

Prioritizing Workforce Stability Amid Labor Market Tightness

Recognizing a 4.1% unemployment rate as a constraint, Weyerhaeuser focused on hiring and talent retention across its segments. Stability in workforce availability ensures operational continuity and supports management's strategic initiatives. However, rising labor costs remain a potential margin-pressure risk-a critical area to monitor for sustained profitability.

urn:contentItem:6GN4-MMM3-RYBN-12KS-00000-00Some evacuation orders lifted three weeks after start of Nova Scotia wildfire2025-09-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:50:23ZLexisNexisATLANTICSome evacuation orders lifted three weeks after start of Nova Scotia wildfireMichael MacDonaldThe Canadian Press

HALIFAX - Three weeks after the Long Lake wildfire in western Nova Scotia forced evacuations and eventually destroyed 20 homes in Annapolis County, fire officials said some evacuation orders would be lifted Wednesday.

Of the almost 500 orders imposed on individual dwellings since Aug. 13, residents living at 360 civic addresses were told Tuesday they would be allowed to return home on a staggered schedule.

“(The province) takes assessing the potential for re-entry very seriously and only recommends it when we’re confident that it is safe," Natural Resources Department spokesman Jim Rudderham told an online briefing.

Provincial officials could not say how many people would be affected by the change, but they had previously indicated that more than 1,000 people in total had been told to evacuate their homes in recent weeks.

Dustin Enslow, deputy warden of Annapolis County, said the decision to lift the orders could be quickly reversed if the fire threatens those areas again.

"We want to make it aware that we are still in an active forest fire situation," Enslow said. "So just because you are returning home, does not mean that we're completely out of the woods yet."

The fire broke out last month near Long Lake, a sparsely populated rural area about 20 kilometres south of Bridgetown, N.S., which is part of Annapolis County. At the time, the fire had quickly grown from three to four square kilometres.

On the weekend of Aug. 23-24, the fire more than doubled in size with strong winds feeding the flames as they advanced toward the community of West Dalhousie, about six kilometres north of Long Lake.

Four days later, officials confirmed the fire had destroyed 20 homes and 11 other buildings. Not all of the homes were primary residences.

The fire has continued to burn out of control amid drought-like conditions, but its advance to the north and east has been stalled by the creation of large fire breaks cut from the woods with heavy equipment.

As a result, homes in the Trout Lake and Highway 10 areas are no longer subject to evacuation orders, Rudderham said. But he said the orders would remain in place for about 140 civic addresses, most of them in the West Dalhousie area. 

"It's still too unsafe in that area," Rudderham said, adding that light rain on the weekend was welcomed by firefighters on the ground but did little to douse the flames.  "It was very spotty."

As of Tuesday afternoon, the fire had grown to cover 84 square kilometres, but there were no new reports of damage.

Still, stressed-out residents have grown weary of dealing with the acrid smell of smoke. Many were spotted wearing facemasks while outside on the weekend.

Scott Tingley, Nova Scotia's forest protection manager, said progress had been made to contain the northern edge of the fire, but he said strong winds were making firefighting difficult along the fire's southern edge.

"And we're back in to a drying trend," Tingley said, adding there is very little rain in the latest weather forecasts.

Exhausted local firefighters in Nova Scotia are receiving help from 61 colleagues from Ontario and 40 from Quebec. Nova Scotia is using 10 helicopters to attack the flames, as well as four 802 Air Tractor aircraft from the Northwest Territories.

Meanwhile, one wildfire in northeastern New Brunswick continued to burn out of control on Tuesday.  The Beaver Lake Stream wildfire in Northumberland County, first reported Aug. 14, covers about five square kilometres.

In Newfoundland and Labrador, the Udjuktok Bay fire in eastern Labrador also continued to burn out of control, about 50 kilometres northwest of Postville. It was first reported on Aug. 8 and had grown to about five square kilometres by Tuesday.

On Saturday, the Newfoundland and Labrador government lifted all remaining evacuation alerts for communities affected by a wildfire in Conception Bay North, where about 200 homes and other buildings have been destroyed since the fire started on Aug. 4.

All evacuation orders for the area were lifted by Friday, when the fire was classified as being held.

This report by The Canadian Press was first published Sept. 2, 2025.

urn:contentItem:6FGJ-DRW3-RTPD-71YF-00000-00Reports from Le Quy Don Technical University Add New Data to Findings in Engineering (Forest Fire Risk Assessment and Mapping Using Remote Sensing and Gis Techniques: a Case Study In Nghe an Province, Vietnam)2025-04-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:50:23ZLexisNexisENGINEERINGReports from Le Quy Don Technical University Add New Data to Findings in Engineering (Forest Fire Risk Assessment and Mapping Using Remote Sensing and Gis Techniques: a Case Study In Nghe an Province, Vietnam)


2025 APR 03 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Disease Prevention Daily -- Investigators publish new report on Engineering. According to news reporting originating from Hanoi, Vietnam, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "This paper presents the results of modeling the risk of forest fires in the west of Nghe An Province (north-central Vietnam) using remote sensing and GIS data. We built models for the occurrence of forest fires using machine learning methods, including Random Forest (RF), Suppor Vector Machine (SVM), and Classification and Regression Trees (CART)."


Financial supporters for this research include Scientific project "Study of the Model of Forecasting Forest Fire Risk Using Geospatial Technologies Using the Example of the Western Region of Ngh An Province, Hanoi University of Mining and Geology (HUMG).
Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from Le Quy Don Technical University, "The models took into account nine factors influencing the risk of forest fires, including vegetation cover (the normalized difference vegetation index (NDVI)), surface evapotranspiration, elevation, slope, aspect, wind speed, ground surface temperature, average monthly precipitation, and population density. Various parameters are tested in the RF, SVM, and CART algorithms to select the algorithm with the highest accuracy in forest fire risk prediction."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "The results show that the RF algorithm with the value of the 'numberOfTrees' parameter equal to 100 has the highest accuracy in predicting the risk of forest fires in the study area."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Forest Fire Risk Assessment and Mapping Using Remote Sensing and Gis Techniques: a Case Study In Nghe an Province, Vietnam. Izvestiya Atmospheric and Oceanic Physics, 2024;60(9):982-991. Izvestiya Atmospheric and Oceanic Physics can be contacted at: Maik Nauka|interperiodica|springer, 233 Spring St, New York, NY 10013-1578, USA. (Springer - www.springer.com; Izvestiya Atmospheric and Oceanic Physics - www.springerlink.com/content/0001-4338/)
The news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting L. H. Trinh, Le Quy Don Technical University, Hanoi, Vietnam. Additional authors for this research include Th. N. Ph. Doan, V. T. Nguyen, X. T. Tran, Th. Th. H. Pham, Th. Th. H. Le, V. Ph. Le and V. R. Zablotskii.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1134/S0001433824700932. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.
Keywords for this news article include: Hanoi, Vietnam, Asia, Engineering, Asia, Remote Sensing, Vietnam, Le Quy Don Technical University.

urn:contentItem:6GKM-BNV3-RS0P-X4NX-00000-00Sanchez will approve en bloc aid for fires and floods of the last three months2025-08-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:50:23ZLexisNexisSanchez will approve en bloc aid for fires and floods of the last three months


The Government will address this Tuesday in the Council of Ministers the declaration of the catastrophic zone of areas affected by the devastating fires of August. But it will not stop there. It also plans to approve en bloc aid for all the territories affected by what it considers to be the ravages of the climatic emergency: uncontrollable fires, flash floods and floods.


The blows of climate change in the last three months in almost all of Spain, in the form of sixth-generation fires with perimeters of hundreds of kilometers but also of floods unthinkable at this time of the year, will monopolize the first Council of Ministers after the summer break. The Executive will declare the autonomous communities of Castilla y León, Galicia, Extremadura, Asturias, Andalusia, Catalonia, Madrid, Valencia, Murcia, Castilla-La Mancha, Cantabria, Aragón, Navarra, La Rioja, the Canary Islands and the Balearic Islands as areas seriously affected by civil protection emergencies, commonly known as catastrophe zones. That is to say, all except Euskadi and the autonomous cities of Ceuta and Melilla, according to governmental sources to EL PAÍS.
The purpose of its application will be to speed up the response of the central Executive in the devastated areas by means of direct aid, tax exemptions and other measures for the tens of thousands of people affected by the fires and floods that have occurred since the end of June. Bureaucratic procedures in emergency contracts will also be facilitated so that municipalities can speed up reconstruction work. The Council of Ministers will also approve, according to several sources in the Executive, a royal decree with the guidelines for the fire prevention plans of the autonomous communities and town councils.
The communities must comply with the obligation established in the Ley De Montes to publish their forest fire prevention, surveillance and extinction plans on an annual basis. A royal decree law approved in August 2022, after another great wave of fires in Spain, reinforced this obligation and urged the Government itself to approve another royal decree with the guidelines on these prevention plans. But the negotiation on this norm has been complicated and the text has not received the approval of the Council of State until the end of July, as EL PAÍS advanced last week.
The declaration of catastrophic area will not be limited to the inferno that, since August 8, has devastated 358,000 hectares according to the European Forest Fire Information System. A tragedy, which has coincided with the most intense heat wave since there are records in Spain (1975), which has shot the area burned over 400,000 hectares. This statement was announced by Pedro Sánchez a week ago during his visit to the Advanced Command Post of the Jarilla fire (Cáceres), the most serious fire in the history of Extremadura with more than 17,000 hectares burned -even though it represents a third of the 45,000 hectares of the Larouco fire in Ourense, the worst since there is data in Galicia, as well as the 41,000 hectares of Uña de Quintana (Zamora) in Castilla y León.
The Government has counted at least 107 fires since August 8, a provisional figure on which the Ministry of the Interior was working late at night and which will undoubtedly rise. The general director of Civil Protection and Emergencies, Virginia Barcones, reported on Monday that there were still more than a dozen large fires active in Zamora, Leon, Asturias and Ourense. Despite the virulence of the flames in August, in La Moncloa they have looked back to June to include more catastrophic areas. In this way, the Government wants to reinforce the idea that they have been caused by phenomena associated with climate change, unlike the PP, whose leader, Alberto Núñez Feijóo, has proposed as a star measure a national register of arsonists. Before the Council of Ministers, Sánchez will chair the meeting of the Interministerial Commission for Climate Change and Energy Transition to address the policies and measures of the State Pact he has proposed, and which the PP rejects, for the mitigation and adaptation to the climate emergency.
One of the most shocking phenomena that the Government will include among the affected areas was the fire that caused the death of two people in Lleida (Catalonia) two months ago. It was the calling card, with a huge cloud of gases that reached 14 kilometers in height and modified the atmospheric conditions, of a season of unpredictable fires with perimeters of 200 kilometers that this month has left four more deaths in the extinction efforts in Castilla y León and Madrid. In July a drought also caused severe flooding in Aragon and forced the deployment of the Military Emergency Unit (UME). The storm also hit hard in Catalonia and the Valencian Community. A few weeks later there was a hail storm in Caravaca de la Cruz that forced relocations and overflowing of wadis in other municipalities of Murcia.
The aid that the Government plans to approve will not be limited to this Council of Ministers, according to several sources in La Moncloa. The reason is that the crisis is not yet over and in the case of most of the fires extinguished in the last two weeks it has not been possible to carry out an exhaustive count of the damages caused. To get an idea of the catastrophe, the Chandrexa de Queixa fire, which started the wave of fires in Galicia on August 8 and has devastated 19,000 hectares, was stabilized on Monday. For this reason, the intention of the Government on Tuesday is to stick to the aid provided by law for this type of emergency situations, regulated in Royal Decree 307/2005. The aids foreseen establish 18,000 euros for death or absolute and permanent disability; a maximum amount of 15,120 euros for the total destruction of the habitual residence; a limit of 10,320 euros for damages to the structure of the habitual residence and a ceiling of 5,160 euros in the case of those that have not affected said structure; a limit of 2.2,580 euros for the destruction or damage of basic household goods of the habitual dwelling, for their replacement or repair; and up to 50% of the technical valuation made by the Insurance Compensation Consortium and with a limit of 9,224 euros in the case of damage to common elements of general use of a community of owners under horizontal property regime.
The Law of the National Civil Protection System also contemplates the adoption of fiscal measures, which have been routinely approved in recent years after the summer fire campaign, the exemption of the quota of the Real Estate Tax affecting dwellings, industrial, tourist and mercantile establishments, agricultural, livestock and forestry exploitations, work premises and similar. Another one would be the reduction in the Tax on Economic Activities, corresponding as in the previous case to this budgetary year, for the industries, mercantile, tourist and professional establishments whose businesses have been damaged.
The Government, which according to the sources consulted is studying the exemption of Personal Income Tax on personal aid, is also considering the exemption of fees for the processing of vehicle cancellations requested as a consequence of the damages produced, as well as the issuance of duplicate circulation or driving licenses destroyed or lost in the fires and floods.
These amounts have been approved in the crises of recent years. The exception was the Valencia dana. Due to its seriousness, with 228 deaths and hundreds of thousands of people affected who lost their homes and other properties, the Government made available aid for the victims and for the reconstruction of the affected regions, which exceeded 16,500 million Euros. The Executive approved then up to 72,000 euros for cases of disability; between 20,000 and 60,000 euros for the repair of damaged homes; up to 10,300 euros to change or repair furniture, electrical appliances and household goods and up to 37,000 euros to repair elements of the neighbors' communities, such as doorways or elevators.

urn:contentItem:6GJT-XT03-RT0W-424J-00000-00Firefighter becomes fourth fatality in Portugal wildfires2025-08-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:50:23ZLexisNexisARTICLEnewsdocumentFirefighter becomes fourth fatality in Portugal wildfires

A firefighter killed in Portugal while battling a wildfire has become the fourth fatality in the emergency the country has faced this summer, the presidency said.

The office of President Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa sent condolences to the family of the fireman "who tragically lost his life after directly combating the forest fires in Sabugal municipality," in the northeast of the country.

The firefighter, aged 45, was working for a private company battling blazes, media reported.

Portugal, with neighbouring Spain, have battled multiple wildfires over the past two months as heatwaves and dry conditions helped flames spread.

Four people have also been killed in Spain during the fire emergency there.

Improved weather conditions are helping firefighters in both countries to bring the blazes under control.

According to the European Forest Fires Information System, around 278,000 hectares have been charred in Portugal this year.

The Iberian Peninsula has been strongly affected by climate change, which has produced heatwaves and lengthy periods of drought, experts say.

Spain's wildfires almost vanquished, says official

Spain has almost beaten back wildfires that swept across the country this month, killing four people and ravaging huge swathes of land, the head of its civil protection and emergencies service said.

"There are fewer of them, and the end is a lot nearer," the official, Virginia Barcones, told state television network TVE.

The ones remaining were still very "treacherous", she said, however, and "we will need a final push to be done with this horrible situation".

Spanish firefighters, helped by other EU countries, have been battling blazes that have scorched a record 403,000 hectares, most of it in the past two weeks, according to the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS).

The regions hardest hit were in the north and the west: Castile and Leon, Extremadura, and Galicia.

The wildfires flared during a heatwave that baked the country for two weeks, sending temperatures to 40C and above.

The fire emergency has thrown a spotlight not only on climate change but also trends that have left Spain's countryside vulnerable.

Castile and Leon suffers from decades of rural exodus, an ageing population, and a decline of farming and livestock grazing that once helped keep forests clear of tinder.

Strong winds that had spread the flames for weeks had weakened recently.

Ms Barcones said there were still 18 active wildfires, with all but one classified at operational level 2, meaning they represent a danger to people and property.

She said she was particularly concerned about a fire in Iguena, in northwest Castile and Leon.

Even so, "the overall feeling is that it is improving, going in the right direction, and that less is burning," she said.

While numerous villages remain evacuated for their inhabitants' safety, many residents have been able to return to their properties since Friday.

The fires have fuelled accusations that politicians mishandled the crisis.

The main opposition party, the conservative Popular Party, has accused Socialist Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez of having withheld aid to damaged regions where its officials govern.

According to EFFIS data analysed by AFP, Spain is one of four EU countries experiencing its worst year for wildfires since statistics began in 2006.

The other three are Cyprus, Germany and Slovakia.

Scientists say climate change is driving longer, more intense and more frequent heatwaves worldwide.

Lower humidity in the air, vegetation and soil makes it easier for wildfires to ignite and harder to control once they spread.

Accreditation: AFP

urn:contentItem:6GM2-M193-S8S1-M1Y4-00000-00Volga-Dnepr Airline Continues to Provide High-Quality Cargo Delivery Services2025-08-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:50:23ZLexisNexisVolga-Dnepr Airline Continues to Provide High-Quality Cargo Delivery Services

Key Highlights:

* Volga-Dnepr has performed periodic technical maintenance on its Il-76TD-90VD and An-124-100/150 aircraft, with 7 and 16 forms completed respectively since January this year.

* The airline has celebrated its 35th anniversary and has faced various crisis situations, but has always found solutions to continue providing high-quality services.

* Volga-Dnepr is considering various options for its further existence and development due to unprecedented sanctions pressure in the transportation industry since 2022.

Original Press Release:

Aug. 28 -- Volga-Dnepr Airlines issued the following news release:

One of the largest freight carriers in Russia is actively preparing for the high freight season in response to expectations from customers and the market.

From September 13, the airline will introduce an additional frequency on the regular route Zhengzhou-Moscow, now flights will be performed three times a week on board its own Il-76TD-90VD aircraft. The third flight will allow the company to fully fulfill all obligations to customers and deliver vital cargo to Moscow and other regions of the country on time. Volga-Dnepr also maintains a regular route from Mumbai (India) and Urumqi (China) in the schedule.

The implementation of the program for regular and charter cargo transportation is impossible without an available fleet. The company's priority remains maintaining the airworthiness of unique transport aircraft - An-124-100/150 and Il-76TD-90VD. Since the foundation of Volga-Dnepr, the company has formed a team of aviation specialists, aircraft technicians and engineers who perform periodic and scheduled maintenance and repair (MRO) of all aircraft. Since January of this year, periodic maintenance has been carried out on the Il-76TD-90VD in the amount of 7 forms, and on the An-124-100/150 in the amount of 16 forms.

"Last week, Volga-Dnepr Airlines celebrated its 35th anniversary. Over the years, we have faced various crises and problems, but the company's management and team have always found solutions to continue providing high-quality and in-demand services for the transportation of various types of cargo. Including within the framework of various partnerships and cooperation. Since 2022, the transport industry has been subject to unprecedented sanctions pressure, which cannot but affect the activities of the largest players. In order to preserve the unique fleet, and most importantly - competent, experienced and qualified specialists, we are considering various options for the further existence and development of the company," said Igor Borisovich Aksenov, General Director of Volga-Dnepr Airlines, whose decision to extend his powers for next year was made this week.

Volga-Dnepr is one of the largest cargo companies with expertise in integrated logistics services. For over thirty-five years, Volga-Dnepr has been delivering cargo to various countries and regions on board An-124-100/150 and Il-76TD-90VD transport aircraft, and also provides services in the field of insurance, MRO (technical maintenance and repair of aircraft), truck delivery and training. The company's logistics services cover all stages of transportation - consultation, design and manufacture of special loading equipment, advice on cargo packaging, organization of multimodal delivery, terminal and warehouse services, last-mile and first-mile delivery. Over the past few years, Volga-Dnepr Airlines has not only successfully developed in traditional areas of regular and charter cargo transportation, but also significantly deepened its expertise and accumulated competencies in new aviation operations and services, such as forest fire services, flight support and technical maintenance and repair.

urn:contentItem:6GM2-9923-RSCJ-F2X3-00000-00Civil Protection considers the next 24 hours "definitive" for the control of the fires.2025-08-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:50:23ZLexisNexisCivil Protection considers the next 24 hours "definitive" for the control of the fires.


The next 24 hours "are definitive" for the control of most of the fires still active in the Peninsula, and to consolidate progress in the fires of Porto and La Igüeña, currently the most worrying. This has been stated by the general director of the public agency, Virgina Barcones, who has shown optimism about the forecast of the fires that continue to burn in Spain.


According to the director, after the progress achieved during Wednesday and the good conditions that are expected for this Thursday, great advances can be achieved during these hours regarding the evolution that can register all these foci. "Yesterday we had a window of opportunity and today we have another one and we hope that all these improvements will allow us to definitively settle this dramatic episode in our history", argued Barcones.
The risk will continue to be "extreme" until Thursday and the weather will be more unfavorable.
The fire risk will continue, however, to be "extreme" until Thursday despite the rains and the improvement of conditions, because the risk is "cumulative" and it must take some time until it is reduced. In addition, Barcones has admitted that from tomorrow the weather situation will not be so favorable for the work of extinction, so it is essential to move forward while the weather permits.
Regarding the evacuations, the general director of Civil Protection has explained that yesterday 14 evacuations took place, but today it is expected the relocation of localities of Ibias (Asturias), of the environment of the fire of Garaño and La Baña in Castilla y León. The good evolution of the extinguishing work has also resulted in a reduction in the number of roads closed, which is limited to three roads in the provinces of León and Zamora.
Civil Protection balance sheet
According to the balance offered by Civil Protection, there are currently 14 active forest fires. Of the total number of fires, six remain stabilized and six are under control.
Castilla y León
As far as Castilla y León is concerned, the Yeres forest fire, in which the situation "is completely stable", and the Barniedo de la Reina and Garaño fires, whose evolution continues to be favorable, are still intact. On the other hand, the Porto fire, in Zamora, is still active but contained within the defense lines, and in the area of La Baña there is "some contained activity". The "most unfavorable" and "most worrying" fire is currently the Igüeña fire "as a consequence of the important gusts of wind".
Asturias
In Asturias, the evolution is also "favorable", specifically in the fires of Cangas de Narcéa and Somiedo. Regarding the Ibias fire, a fire with convective behavior and high suction potential, there has also been an improvement and a favorable evolution is expected in the next hours.
Galicia
Among the fires that are already in operational situation one, although they are still active, are the two fires in Galicia, both in Pobra do Brollón (Lugo) and Carballeda de Valdehorras (Orense). The latter, according to estimates, has already affected around 5,000 hectares, which makes it one of the most serious fires recorded this summer in the region.
As for the deployed means of the National Response Mechanism, means from Catalonia, Valencia and La Rioja are operating in Castilla y León; in Galicia means from Valencia and in Asturias means from Navarra. Also, the troops arriving from the Czech Republic have returned to their countries of origin and this Friday will do so from Slovakia, as well as from the Netherlands, which will carry out this day the last flights over the fire of Igüeña.

urn:contentItem:6GM2-96P3-RT4F-V2RM-00000-00Spain faces worst fires since 1994; over 400,000 hectares devastated2025-08-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:50:23ZLexisNexisSpain faces worst fires since 1994; over 400,000 hectares devastated


SPAIN - Forest fires raging in Spain have reached historic levels. According to the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS), 402,903 hectares have burned so far in 2025, surpassing any annual record since 1994, when 437,602 hectares were lost.


A scenario comparable to the worst years
The current balance places 2025 as the third most devastating year in area burned, behind only 1985, with 483,843 hectares, and 1994, which was also the deadliest, with 31 deaths and 204 injuries, according to data from the National Wildfire Information Coordination Center, according to Reuters.
This year's figure is five times higher than the average for the period 2006-2024, which stood at 79,570 hectares.
Of the 10 largest fires recorded in Spain, five occurred this August in the province of Ourense, in the northwest of the country, one of the areas hardest hit by fire. Photo: Image bankOurense, epicenter of the flames
Of the 10 largest fires recorded in Spain, five occurred this August in the province of Ourense, in the northwest of the country, one of the areas most severely affected by fire.
Portugal also under emergency
The wave of fires has affected neighboring Portugal, where the EFFIS reported 261,863 hectares burned, almost triple the average recorded between 2006 and 2024.
These are the worst fires in that country since 2017, when 114 people died and 563 thousand 530 hectares were burned.
Unprecedented heat wave
The origin of the crisis lies in a 16-day heat wave, with temperatures of up to 45 ºC, unprecedented for this time of the year, according to Spain's State Meteorological Agency.
The episode ended last Monday, giving way to a drop in temperatures below 40 ºC, accompanied by higher humidity and rain in some regions.
Progress in extinction
The new weather conditions have given the authorities some respite. In Castilla y León, the regional president Alfonso Fernández Mañueco assured that "conditions are favorable and significant progress is being made in extinguishing the fire".
With these data, Spain and Portugal are facing one of the most devastating summers in terms of forest fires, marking a new challenge for emergency management and climate disaster prevention.
Spain suffers the most intense heat wave since records have been kept
The State Meteorological Agency (AEMET) reported that the heat wave that hit Spain for 16 days in August was "the most intense since records have been kept" in the country.
According to its provisional data, temperatures were 4.6 ºC above normal, surpassing the record of July 2022, when the deviation was 4.5 ºC, according to DW.
The wave ended on August 18, but the period between August 8 and 17 became the warmest set of ten consecutive days recorded in Spain since at least 1950, the AEMET highlighted on the X social network.
An increasingly frequent phenomenon
Since 1975, 77 heat waves have been recorded in Spain, and six of them had a thermal anomaly of 4 ºC or more. Alarmingly, five of those episodes have occurred since 2019, evidence of a worsening of climate extremes in the region.
According to estimates by the Carlos III Health Institute, more than 1,100 deaths are attributed to this heat wave, almost triple those recorded in July during the previous episode.
Devastating fires on the Iberian Peninsula
The extreme heat also favored the spread of large forest fires in Spain and Portugal, which so far have left eight dead, four in each country, and more than 400,000 hectares razed together.

urn:contentItem:6FRC-T043-RV5W-W1VK-00000-00Northern Ireland firefighters mop up weekend forest fire2025-04-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:50:23ZLexisNexisTODAY'S STORIESNorthern Ireland firefighters mop up weekend forest fire

By Associated Press LONDON - Firefighters in Northern Ireland were mopping up after a significant fire swept through forest land in the southeastern corner of the province over the weekend as concerns grow about unseasonably warm, dry weather across the United Kingdom. The Northern Ireland Fire and Rescue Service declared a major incident at 11:53 p.m. local time Saturday and more than 100 firefighters and 14 pieces of equipment were deployed in a rural area outside the community of Hilltown.

The blaze was under control by the early hours of Sunday. The fire is believed to have been deliberately started, the fire service said. Authorities in Northern Ireland on March 28 decried a recent spate of deliberately set wildfires across the region. "People lighting these fires may be putting their own and others' lives at risk including the fire service personnel and other emergency services tasked to deal with them," Andrew Muir, minister for the Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs, said in a statement. Firefighters across the U.K. were on alert over the weekend due to the increased risk of fires following a spate of warm spring weather. Police in Scotland advised people to avoid the Loch Doon area of East Ayrshire because of a wildfire burning in the southwestern part of Scotland. A number of fires were also burning on Bodmin Moor in Cornwall, southwestern England. Devon and Cornwall police advised travelers to avoid the area as they have closed a number of roads in the Bolventor area to assist firefighters.

urn:contentItem:6G93-B7C3-RSBH-50XD-00000-00Brace for more smoky skies as Canadian wildfires rage2025-07-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:50:23ZLexisNexisNATURAL DISASTERS NEWS & CANADA NEWSBrace for more smoky skies as Canadian wildfires rageDoyle Rice, USA TODAY

Smoke from Canadian wildfires again plagued portions of the northern United States on July 16, prompting air quality alerts from Illinois to Maine.

This includes portions of Michigan, where the National Weather Service said that due to the wildfire smoke, "it is recommended that, when possible, you stay indoors and keep time outdoors short and avoid strenuous activities."

The smoke is coming from 81 uncontrolled active wildfires in Canada across several provinces, including British Columbia, Alberta, Manitoba and Saskatchewan.

Smoke to continue

Smoke from western Canadian fires is forecast to continue to impact portions of the United States for the near future, forecasters said on July 16, as fires are expected to persist: "We expect that there is a high potential for wildfires in the next three months," atmospheric scientist Djordje Romanic of McGill University told USA TODAY in an e-mail July 16.

This includes a dire forecast map for August from the Canadian government, which shows that most of the four huge western Canadian provinces (British Columbia, Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba) all face "well above average" fire severity.

AccuWeather meteorologist Paul Pastelok told USA TODAY that the wildfires are likely to continue well into October in Canada, so smoke will continue to be an issue in the United States into the fall.

'A pretty bad situation'

While our northern neighbor's wildfire season hasn't been as bad as the record-shattering 2023 season, the province of Manitoba is enduring its worst year for wildfires in roughly three decades, according to the Manitoba government. The province remains under a state of emergency due to the fires.

The weather forecast for the next couple of weeks in fire-plagued Manitoba shows little relief from the dry conditions that have plagued the western provinces since the late spring, Environment Canada meteorologist Crawford Luke told USA TODAY on July 16. "It's a pretty bad situation," he said.

Although the number of fires in Canada is average for this time of year, the area burned to date is significantly more than the 10-year average, according to the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre (CIFFC).

And according to the Canadian government, "Canada is at National Preparedness Level 5, indicating that there is full commitment of national resources and demand for interagency resources through the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Center is extreme. Since national availability of resources is limited, international resources are being mobilized."

What should I do when an air quality alert is issued?

According to Michigan's Department of Health and Human Services, here are some indoor methods to protect yourself from the pollutants outside:

◾Close windows and keep outside doors shut.

◾Run the air conditioning. If your air conditioner has a fresh air option, close the intake.

◾Use an air filter (rated MERV-13 or better) to capture fine particles from smoke.

◾Avoid activities that create pollution, such as frying foods, sweeping, burning candles, vacuuming and smoking tobacco or other products.

◾Seek shelter elsewhere if you do not have an air conditioner and it is too warm to stay inside with the windows closed. Call or contact your local health department to find out if there is a shelter or cooling center nearby. Or consider spending time in an air-conditioned public place such as a library, mall, movie theater, etc.

Contributing: Sarah Moore, Lansing State Journal

urn:contentItem:6GR2-6D83-RS56-V13R-00000-00CENIBRA MONITORS AREAS AFFECTED BY FIRES AND INTENSIFIES PREVENTION2025-09-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:50:23ZLexisNexisCENIBRA MONITORS AREAS AFFECTED BY FIRES AND INTENSIFIES PREVENTION

Key Highlights:

* CENIBRA's preservation areas serve as refuges for various animal and tree species.

* The company expands its preventive actions against forest fires through strategic partnerships.

* Monitoring affected areas allows CENIBRA to guide future recovery interventions and reduce fire propagation risk.

Original Press Release:

Sept. 9 -- CENIBRA issued the following news release:

Nature looks you in the eye and cries for help. The fires recorded by CENIBRA in 2024 endangered people's lives and left thousands of hectares of forest devastated. The company's conservation areas are true refuges, home to several animal species and emblematic trees of the Atlantic Forest. To this end, CENIBRA is expanding its preventive actions to combat forest fires through strategic partnerships.

The areas impacted by the fires currently show significant vegetation loss, with direct consequences for society and local biodiversity. Monitoring the affected areas allows us to track the progression of the damage and guide future recovery efforts.

For Igor Geraldo, coordinator of CENIBRA's Forest Fire Prevention Group, it's important to detect and control fires in their early stages. This significantly reduces the risk of fire spread. "Each devastated hectare represents an irreparable loss. Therefore, our main focus is to minimize the occurrence of new fires," emphasizes Igor.

Impacts reveal the urgency of prevention

The 2024 fires in CENIBRA's forests highlight the extent of the damage caused to local biodiversity. The affected areas have experienced significant loss of vegetation cover, compromising natural habitats that were home to some of the 575 species of flora and 1,214 species of fauna cataloged by the company.

Some areas that once served as ecological corridors for species movement now show discontinuity, further fragmenting an already threatened biome. Continuous monitoring of these regions allows us to document the slow natural recovery and assess what future interventions could accelerate this process.

Data collected by CENIBRA's Monitoring Center reveals worrying patterns: 35.61% of incidents occur on weekends. This information supports the strengthening of prevention strategies that combine awareness campaigns, technical training, and the improvement of technological resources.

Nature looks you in the eyes

CENIBRA continually invests in cutting-edge technology to prevent and combat fires. Drones, automatic detection cameras, and monitoring systems are used to identify fire outbreaks in real time and enable a rapid response from specialized teams.

In addition to advanced technology, there's also awareness-raising work. CENIBRA maintains a permanent #ChegaDeFogoNaFloresta campaign, which this year brought deeper reflection through the message "Nature looks you in the eye." The initiative emphasizes that every action, no matter how small, contributes significantly to the preservation of biodiversity and life.

Active public participation is essential, which is why CENIBRA provides free communication channels to facilitate the reporting of criminal activity. Citizens can call 0800 283 1291 or WhatsApp (31) 97354-3333 to report any suspicious activity.

Collective responsibility

CENIBRA's performance in fire prevention and control is remarkable. This result is the result of consistent investments in technology, employee training, and synergy among strategic partners.

Joining forces enhances environmental protection, expands emergency response capacity, and strengthens the culture of prevention throughout the eastern Minas Gerais region, demonstrating in practice the concept of shared responsibility that guides CENIBRA's sustainability actions.

"When companies and institutions speak with one voice about prevention, we can raise awareness among a much larger number of people," says Dbora Jorge, Corporate Communications Coordinator at CENIBRA.

The firefighting campaign "Where there's fire out of control, there's destruction. Preserve, don't destroy" is an initiative of FIEMG Regional Vale do Ao, Aperam, CENIBRA, and Usiminas, through the Corporate Communications technical group of the entity's Strategic Council.

The goal is to alert urban and rural populations about the damage caused by forest fires and their environmental, social, and economic impacts, as well as the risks to human health. Reinforcing that illegal burning is an environmental crime, and those who cause it put lives in danger. In the event of forest fires, call the Fire Department - Dial 193.

About CENIBRA

Established on September 13, 1973, and located in eastern Minas Gerais, Celulose Nipo-Brasileira SA (CENIBRA) operates an industrial unit in the municipality of Belo Oriente, Minas Gerais, with two bleached short-fiber eucalyptus pulp production lines and an installed capacity of 1,200,000 tons/year. The company operates in 54 municipalities in Minas Gerais, employing approximately 8,000 employees and contractors. It has a 24-hour monitoring center and a team dedicated to identifying and locating fires within its forest base, protecting a biodiversity refuge home to 575 tree species, including 26 endangered species.

More information: comunicacaocorporativa@cenibra.com.br | 0800 283 3829.
